questions.text: A newborn is delivered with a protrusion of abdominal viscera covered by a peritoneal sac through the anterior abdominal wall. The defect is located at the base of the umbilical cord. Physical examination reveals the presence of a membranous sac encasing the eviscerated organs. Which of the following terms best describes this congenital anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Exomphalos:

  • Exomphalos, also known as omphalocele, is a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by the protrusion of abdominal viscera through a defect in the anterior abdominal wall.
  • The key feature that distinguishes exomphalos from other abdominal wall defects like gastroschisis is the presence of a membranous sac covering the herniated organs. This sac is composed of the peritoneum and amnion.
  • Membranous Sac: The abdominal organs herniate into a translucent sac, which is usually covered by amnion and peritoneum. This sac is visible at the base of the umbilical cord.
  • Location: The defect is typically located at the base of the umbilical cord.
  • Content: Organs such as intestines and liver may be present in the sac.
  • Clinical Significance: Exomphalos is diagnosed prenatally through ultrasound, and the management involves surgical correction after birth. The goal is to return the herniated organs to the abdominal cavity and close the defect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gastroschisis:

  • Gastroschisis is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents, usually the intestines, protrude through a hole in the abdominal wall.
  • Unlike exomphalos, there is no membranous sac covering the eviscerated organs.
  • Location: typically located to the right of the umbilical cord.

Option C - Hernia umbilicalis:

  • Hernia umbilicalis refers to a herniation of abdominal contents through an opening in the umbilical ring.
  • It is typically not associated with a sac covering the herniated organs.

Option D - Pentalogy of Cantrell:

  • Pentalogy of Cantrell is a rare congenital condition characterized by a midline thoracoabdominal wall defect.
  • It involves a combination of five anomalies: a lower sternal defect, a defect in the diaphragmatic pericardium, an anterior diaphragmatic hernia, a defect in the abdominal wall, and various cardiac malformations.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with a three-month history of progressive weakness, particularly noticeable in the proximal muscles. The patient also reports difficulty with getting up from a seated position and climbing stairs. On examination, muscle strength is diminished, and deep tendon reflexes are reduced. Electromyography (EMG) reveals a characteristic pattern of low-amplitude compound muscle action potentials that increase with repetitive nerve stimulation. Further testing reveals the presence of voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what pathophysiological mechanism underlies the observed findings?

choices.text: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Loss of anterior horn cells
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS); Impaired release of acetylcholine
Myasthenia gravis; Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors
Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS); Demyelination of peripheral nerves

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS):

  • LEMS is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly affecting the proximal muscles.
  • The pathophysiological mechanism in LEMS involves autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCC) on the presynaptic nerve terminals.
  • These antibodies lead to impaired release of acetylcholine (ACh) from the nerve terminals into the synaptic cleft.
  • As a result, the neuromuscular transmission is compromised, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Proximal muscle weakness.
  • Difficulty with activities requiring muscle strength, such as climbing stairs or getting up from a seated position.
  • Autonomic symptoms such as dry mouth, impotence, and decreased sweating may also be present.

Diagnostic Findings:

  • Electromyography (EMG) typically reveals a characteristic pattern of low-amplitude compound muscle action potentials that increment (increase) with repetitive nerve stimulation.
  • Antibodies against VGCC are often detected in the serum, confirming the autoimmune nature of the disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Loss of anterior horn cells:

  • Description: ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of motor neurons, including anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and motor cortex.
  • Differentiation: Unlike LEMS, ALS does not involve autoimmune mechanisms affecting neuromuscular transmission. EMG findings in ALS typically show denervation patterns.

Option C - Myasthenia gravis; Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors:

  • Description: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by antibodies against acetylcholine receptors, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • Differentiation: Unlike LEMS, myasthenia gravis does not involve VGCC antibodies, and its characteristic EMG findings include decremental response during repetitive nerve stimulation

Option D - Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS); Demyelination of peripheral nerves:

  • Description: GBS is an acute immune-mediated neuropathy affecting peripheral nerves, leading to demyelination.
  • Clinical Features: Ascending weakness, often following an infection.
  • Differentiation: Unlike LEMS, GBS does not involve the presynaptic nerve terminal or impaired acetylcholine release.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with hematuria and proteinuria. Renal biopsy reveals thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Immunohistochemistry demonstrates the presence of a collagen type that is specifically associated with basement membrane formation. Which type of collagen is primarily responsible for the structural integrity of basement membranes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Collagen Type IV:

  • This type of collagen is a major component of basement membranes. Basement membranes provide structural support and act as a selective barrier in various tissues, including the glomerular basement membrane in the kidneys.
  • Clinical Relevance: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, as seen in the renal biopsy of the patient, is a characteristic feature of conditions like Alport syndrome and membranous nephropathy.
  • Alport syndrome, in particular, is associated with mutations in genes encoding collagen Type IV, leading to structural abnormalities in basement membranes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Collagen Type I:

  • Predominantly found in connective tissues such as bone, skin, and tendons. Not a major component of basement membranes.

Option B - Collagen Type II:

  • Mainly found in cartilage. Not a major component of basement membranes.

Option C - Collagen Type III:

  • Found in skin, blood vessels, and internal organs. It is not a major constituent of basement membranes.

questions.text: A 40 year old presents with a nodule in the anterior neck. She had a history of radiation exposure. On FNAC, Orphan Annie eye nucleus is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid:

  • Most common thyroid cancer.
  • Histology shows empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing ("Orphan Annie" eyes), psammoma bodies and nuclear grooves.
  • Papillary carcinoma: most prevalent, palpable lymph nodes.
  • It has a good prognosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hashimoto thyroiditis:

  • The image above shows thyroid parenchyma containing a dense lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal centres. Residual thyroid follicles lined by deeply eosinophilic Hürthle cells are also seen.
  • These findings are consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Hashimoto thyroiditis:

  • Also called chronic autoimmune thyroiditis.
  • The most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions.
  • Associated with HLA-DR3 (differs by ethnicity) and increased risk of primary thyroid lymphoma (typically diffuse large B-cell lymphoma).

Findings:

  • Moderately enlarged, non-tender thyroid.
  • It may be preceded by a transient hyperthyroid state ("Hashitoxicosis") due to follicular rupture and thyroid hormone release.

Serology:

  • Positive anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-microsomal) and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies.

Histology:

  • Hürthle cells and lymphoid aggregates with germinal centres

Option B - Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis:

  • Also called de Quervain thyroiditis.
  • Usually, a self-limited disease.
  • Often preceded by viral infection.
  • Findings are raised ESR, jaw pain, and very tender thyroid (de Quervain is associated with pain).
  • Histology shows granulomatous inflammation, typical lesion characterized by central core of colloid surrounded by multinucleated giant cells

Option D - Reidel's thyroiditis:

  • Also called invasive fibrous thyroiditis.
  • It may be associated with IgG4-related disease (e.g., autoimmune pancreatitis, retroperitoneal fibrosis, noninfectious aortitis), a variant of autoimmune thyroiditis, or part of a systemic fibrosing disorder.
  • Hypothyroidism occurs in 1 ⁄3 of patients.
  • Fibrosis may extend to local structures (e.g., trachea, oesophagus), mimicking anaplastic carcinoma.
  • Findings: slowly enlarging, hard (rocklike), fixed, nontender thyroid.
  • Histology: thyroid replaced by fibrous tissue and inflammatory infiltrate (Shown below).

questions.text: Name the drug of choice for acute termination of Paroxysmal supra ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Adenosine:

  • It is the drug of choice for Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
  • It is used to induce brief coronary vasodilatation during certain diagnostic/interventional procedures
  • It is used to produce controlled hypotension during surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lidocaine:

  • It is the most commonly used local anesthetic
  • It is a popular antiarrhythmic in intensive care units
  • It is used to suppress VT and prevent VF

Option C - Clonidine:

  • It belongs to central sympatholytics
  • It is used in the treatment of hypertension

Option D - Mexiletine:

  • It is a local anesthetic and an orally active antiarrhythmic
  • Parenteral Mexiletine may be used in post-infarction sinister ventricular arrhythmias as an alternative to lidocaine

questions.text: A 40-year-old female from Tamil Nadu presents to the clinic with subcutaneous swelling of the foot producing abscesses. On examination, the abscess is with seropurulent fluid containing red granules. She was treated with Sulphonamides and Antibiotics. Which is the causative agent of the above-mentioned disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- A. pelletieri

  • This Actinomycetoma produces red granules

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Streptomyces somaliensis: It produces yellow granules

Option B - Actinomadura madurai: It produces white-yellow granules

Option D - M.grisea: It produces black granules

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern that is shown below. Which among the following is depicted it?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Whorl:

  • It forms 25% of fingerprint patterns
  • The ridges form a series of circles or spirals around a core

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Arch:

  • It forms 6-7% of population
  • Diverges
  • Just like mountain

Option C - Loop:

  • Loop (common): 70% of the population
  • Like hairpin
  • Ridges come towards each other

Option D - Composite:

  • Least common; 1-3% of the population
  • Mixed pattern

questions.text: In a busy clinical setting, a patient undergoes a diagnostic procedure and receives treatment for a chronic medical condition. Subsequently, the healthcare team disposes of used urine bags and catheters, classifying them as biomedical waste. To adhere to proper waste management protocols, in which of the following bags should these biomedical waste items be appropriately discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Red bag:

  • Urine bags and catheters as biomedical waste will be disposed of in red bags.
  • Cat 7: Solid / Contaminated / Recyclable waste (gloves, tubings, bottles, urine bags, syringes without needles, vacutainers).
  • Disposal: Autoclaving (AC) / Hydroclaving (HC) / Microwaving (MW) followed by destruction/shredding.
    • Later used in road making/fuel, oil/energy recovery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Yellow bag:

  • Cat 1: Human anatomical waste (placenta, gall bladder amputated limb, appendix).
  • Cat 2: Animal waste
  • Cat 6: Soiled waste (gauge piece, bandage, dressing, swab).
    • Disposable: Incineration / PP (Plasmapheresis).
    • Placenta disposal: Deep burial.
  • Cat 10: Chemical Waste- Incineration / PP / Encapsulation.
  • Cat 5: Discarded medicines- Incineration / PP / Encapsulation.
  • Cat 8: Liquid waste- Chemical treatment followed by the drain.

Option C - White container:

  • Cat 4: Waste sharps (needles, scalpel blades, burnt needles, syringes with fixed needles).
  • Disposal: AC / dry heat followed by shredding/mutilation encapsulation · Later send to foundries /landfills / sharp pits.

Option D - Blue bag:

  • Non-recyclable general waste is disposed of in Blue bins.
  • Broken glass and Metallic implants glassware.

questions.text: A patient, who is a teacher, presented to the hospital with complaints of hoarseness of voice, increased effort to speak, and neck pain on prolonged talking. On examination, the pathology is found to be at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords and is bilaterally symmetric. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vocal nodule:

  • These are caused due to chronic voice abuse.
  • Vocal Nodules occur at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cord. These are bilateral lesions and are usually sessile masses.
  • First-line management involves resting your voice and voice therapy. If symptoms fail to improve, microscopic excision of the nodules can be done. Care must be taken to avoid damage to the vocal cords.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vocal polyp:

  • It is caused by sudden voice abuse. (sudden shouting)
  • Polyps are unilateral lesions.
  • Polyps are usually pedunculated masses.
  • Treatment includes excision by micro laryngeal surgery.

Option C - Tuberculosis of the larynx:

  • Tuberculosis of the larynx occurs predominantly secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. Tubercle bacilli from the bronchi penetrate the laryngeal mucosa causing swelling and redness. Later, these tubercles undergo caseation and eventually ulcerate.
  • Symptoms include weakness of voice and severe pain when talking, along with odynophagia. The posterior part of the larynx is more commonly involved than the anterior part.
  • Diagnosis includes sputum examination, X-ray chest, and biopsy to rule out carcinoma.
  • Treatment includes initiation of ATT(anti-tuberculosis therapy) and voice rest.

Option D - Laryngeal papillomas:

  • Laryngeal Papilloma means finger-like projections.
  • These are caused by human papillomaviruses - 6 and 11 and are the most common benign laryngeal neoplasms in children.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, weakness, and malaise. On examination, right-sided proptosis and consequent restriction of movements in the right eye are seen. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Orbital cellulitis:

  • Following are the features to identify the cases of orbital cellulitis:
  • Unilateral proptosis
  • Painful Proptosis · Restriction of eye movements due to proptosis ( No nerve involvement)
  • Decreased visual acuity
  • Lid oedema / Conjunctival congestion / Chemosis
  • Fever, Weakness, Malaise

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior orbital fissure syndrome:

  • Ophthalmoplegia - The eye may not be able to perform ocular movements controlled by 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerves. Selective paresis may also be possible if a single nerve is involved
  • Proptosis is bulging one or both of your eyes from their natural position.Loss of corneal sensations due to involvement of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.
  • It is orbital apex syndrome when all these symptoms are associated with optic nerve involvement.

Option C - Rhino orbital cerebral mucormycosis:

  • It is similar to orbital cellulitis.
  • It is caused my mucor fungus which is also called black fungus because it causes tissue ischemia, leading to tissue necrosis.
  • There is a risk of complications like CRAO and CRVO.

Option D - Carotid Cavernous Fistula:

  • It is a triad of Pulsating proptosis, Chemosis, and Bruit(whoosh sounds)

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman complains of a sudden, strong urge to urinate, leading to involuntary leakage. This has been occurring frequently, and she sometimes cannot reach the bathroom in time. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis for her urinary symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Urge incontinence:

  • Urge incontinence is characterized by a sudden, intense urge to urinate, often followed by an involuntary loss of urine.
  • It is commonly associated with overactivity of the detrusor muscle in the bladder, which contracts too often, causing the urge to urinate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Overflow incontinence:

  • This type of incontinence occurs when the bladder doesn't completely empty during urination, leading to frequent leakage of small amounts of urine.
  • It is often associated with conditions that obstruct the normal flow of urine, such as an enlarged prostate in men or a tumor pressing on the bladder.

Option C - Stress incontinence:

  • Stress incontinence involves the involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, laughing, or exercising.
  • It is often related to weakened pelvic floor muscles and sphincters, commonly seen in women after childbirth or due to aging.

Option D - Neurogenic incontinence:

  • Neurogenic incontinence is associated with a neurological disorder that affects the normal functioning of the bladder.
  • Conditions such as spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, or nerve damage can disrupt the signals between the Spinal cord and the bladder, leading to either overactive or underactive bladder function.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccinations are given at birth?

choices.text: MMR, Typhoid, JE-1, bOPV-2, Vitamin A

questions.solution:
Correct Option A-BCG, OPV, Hepatitis B:

  • These are the vaccines given at birth according to the national immunization schedule.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - MMR, Typhoid, JE-1, bOPV-2, Vitamin A:

  • These vaccines are not given at birth.

  • MMR1, JE1, Vitamin A, and fIPV3 are given at 9-12 months and bOPV2 is given at 10 weeks.

  • So this cannot be the answer.

Option C - OPV, MMR, BCG:

  • OPV and BCG are given at birth, but not MR

  • MMR-1 is given at 9 months

  • So this cannot be the answer

Option D - BCG, Hepatitis B, Vitamin A:

  • Hepatitis B and BCG are given at birth, but not Vitamin A

  • Vitamin A is given at 9 months

  • So this cannot be the answer

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency room after sustaining thermal burns in a house fire. On examination, the healthcare team estimates the extent of burn injuries using the rule of nines. The patient has full-thickness burns involving both lower extremities (front and back) and the anterior trunk. Additionally, the patient has superficial burns on the face. According to the rule of nines, what percentage of the total body surface area is affected by the burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 58.5%:

  • The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. This rule divides the body into anatomical regions, each accounting for a specific percentage of the TBSA.
  • Here's a breakdown according to the Rule of Nines:
    • Head and neck: 9%
    • Anterior trunk: 18%
    • Posterior trunk: 18%
    • Each upper extremity: 9% (total for both: 18%)
    • Each lower extremity: 18% (total for both: 36%)
    • Genitalia: 1%
  • In this scenario:
  • The full-thickness burns involving both lower extremities (front and back) contribute to 36% of TBSA (18% for each lower extremity).
  • The anterior trunk involvement accounts for 18%.
  • The superficial burns of anterior face are typically estimated to be around 4.5% (half of the head and neck area, which is 9%).
  • Calculation:
  • Lower extremities (36%) + Anterior trunk (18%) + anterior head (4.5%) = 58.5%
  • Therefore, the correct answer is not among the options provided. If choosing the closest option based on the estimated TBSA affected by the burns, it would be approximately 54%, closest to option E (54%). However, the most accurate calculation based on the Rule of Nines would exceed the given options, as it totals to around 58.5%.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She reports no specific complaints, but on examination, the physician notices diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles. The patient denies any recent illnesses, and her medical history is unremarkable. Laboratory tests reveal a positive rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test and a positive treponemal test. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Secondary syphilis:

  • The patient's presentation with a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles, along with positive rapid plasma reagin (RPR) and positive treponemal tests, is highly indicative of secondary syphilis. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.
  • In secondary syphilis, patients often develop a systemic illness characterized by a skin rash, Mucosal erosions, and systemic symptoms. The rash in secondary syphilis is typically maculopapular and involves the palms and soles, which is a distinctive feature. Other common manifestations of secondary syphilis may include mucous patches (grayish-white lesions) in the oral cavity and genital region, as well as flu-like symptoms such as fever and malaise.
  • Laboratory testing for syphilis includes both non-treponemal tests (such as RPR) and treponemal tests. In this case, the positive RPR and positive treponemal test results confirm the diagnosis of syphilis, with the RPR indicating the presence of antibodies against cardiolipin, a substance released by damaged host cells and treponemal tests detecting antibodies specifically against Treponema pallidum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primary syphilis:

  • Primary syphilis is characterized by the development of a painless chancre at the site of T. pallidum inoculation. The skin rash seen in this patient is more indicative of secondary syphilis.

Option C - Tertiary syphilis:

  • Tertiary syphilis occurs years after the initial infection and can involve the cardiovascular system, central nervous system, and other organs. It is characterized by gummatous lesions and neurosyphilis. The presentation in this case is more consistent with secondary syphilis.

Option D - Latent syphilis:

  • Latent syphilis is characterized by the absence of clinical symptoms. It is further classified into early latent (within the first year of infection) and late latent (more than one year after infection). The patient's presentation with a rash and positive serologic test indicates active disease and is not consistent with latent syphilis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with concerns about the appearance of prominent, bulging veins in her lower legs. She reports aching pain and heaviness in her legs, particularly after prolonged periods of standing. The patient notes that the symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few years. Which among the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Duplex Scan:

  • IOC for Dx of varicose veins - Duplex Scan

  • Duplex Scan assesses:

    • Status of SFJ → If it is Competent / Incompetent.

    • Status & location of SPJ → Competent / Incompetent.

    • Perforators → Numbers & Location of Incompetent perforators.

    • DVT (+ /-) → DVT is an absolute Contraindication for stripping.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Elastography:

  • Elasto = elasticity, graphy = study

  • It is a study about the loss of elasticity

  • Used to differentiate benign lesions from malignant lesions.

  • Not an investigation for varicose veins

Option C - Contrast Enhancement Ultrasound (CEUS):

  • It is not a first-line investigation for varicose veins

Option D - Angiography:

  • It is not a first-line investigation for varicose veins

questions.text: Identify the instrument used to secure the airway in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Laryngeal mask airway:

  • A supraglottic airway device is called the laryngeal mask airway. It is a good substitute for bag-valve-mask ventilation, freeing the provider's hands while providing the advantage of reduced stomach distention.
  • It was created for use in the operating room as elective ventilation.
  • The LMA was initially primarily employed in the operating room setting. Still, it has recently started to be used in the emergency setting as a crucial auxiliary device for managing the challenging airway.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Endotracheal tube:

  • Endotracheal tubes provide proper anesthesia for the patient.
  • This tube has markings as follows:
    • ID: the internal diameter of the tube.
    • OD: the outer diameter of the tube.
  • Endotracheal tubes can be oral or nasal. It is an infraglottic airway device.

Incorrect Options:

  • R-A-E tube (Ring Adair Elwyn)

  • The RAE tube is also known as the "south pole tube" (universal connector facing towards the lower part of 'the' patient) or the "north pole tube" (universal connector facing towards the head of the patient), depending on the bend of the tube.
  • These are easy to secure and keep the breathing circuit away from the surgical ﬁeld.
  • They are used for oro-maxillofacial surgery.

Option C - Flexometallic tube:

  • These have metallic wiring inside, which makes them kink- resistant.
  • The tube bends easily. Hence, we have to use stellate.
  • These are used in the prone position for neurosurgery and spine surgery. A normal PCV tube can get compressed, leading to obstruction of oxygen or inhalational agents. This is prevented by the ﬂexometallic tube.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with a noticeable bump on the back of his right distal femur. He reports that the bump has been present for several years and has gradually increased in size. On examination, a hard, painless, and immobile mass is palpated on the posterior aspect of the right distal femur. An x-ray was done as given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteochondroma (Exostosis):

  • Osteochondroma, or exostosis, is a benign bone tumor characterized by an outgrowth of bone and cartilage, usually originating from the metaphysis near the growth plate.

  • It commonly presents as a painless bony lump, often discovered incidentally.

  • Arises from metaphysis

  • The hallmark feature of osteochondroma is the stalk-like projection extending from the underlying bone.

  • The lesion grows away from the joint, and the bony and cartilaginous components are well-defined on X-ray. Given the clinical presentation and radiographic findings described in the case, osteochondroma is the most likely diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ewing's Sarcoma:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and young adults. It typically presents with bone pain, swelling, and tenderness.

  • Arises from diaphysis

  • On imaging, Ewing's sarcoma may show a permeative bone pattern, aggressive periosteal reaction, and soft tissue involvement.

  • In the given case, the painless bony lump and the well-defined outgrowth of bone and cartilage are not characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.

Option C - Giant cell tumor:

  • Giant cell tumor (GCT) is a locally aggressive benign bone tumor that typically affects young adults. It commonly occurs around the knee, and the presentation includes localized pain, swelling, and limited joint mobility.Arises from epiphysis

  • On imaging, GCT may show a characteristic soap-bubble appearance with well-defined borders and expansile growth. The hard, immobile mass with a stalk-like projection described in the case is not consistent with the typical features of a giant cell tumor.

Option D - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly occurs in children and young adults. It typically presents with bone pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.

  • Unlike osteochondroma, which is a benign tumor, osteosarcoma is aggressive and can metastasize to other parts of the body.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of auditory hallucinations, withdrawal of thoughts, controlled feelings, and delusional perceptions such as ‘’ I saw the moon and I immediately knew he was evil. There is no history of substance abuse or other medical conditions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Schizophrenia:

  • This patient presents with a combination of positive and negative symptoms that are consistent with a diagnosis of schizophrenia. The positive symptoms include auditory hallucinations (hearing voices commenting on his actions) and paranoid delusions (believing in a conspiracy against him). The disorganized speech is an example of a formal thought disorder, which is commonly seen in schizophrenia.
  • The negative symptoms observed in this patient include indifference to appearance, lack of motivation, and reduced emotional expressiveness. These symptoms collectively indicate the presence of schizophrenia, a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by a combination of positive, negative, and cognitive symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Major depressive disorder:

  • Major depressive disorder primarily presents with symptoms of persistent low mood, feelings of worthlessness, changes in appetite and sleep patterns, and reduced energy. While individuals with schizophrenia may experience depressive symptoms, the presence of positive symptoms (hallucinations, delusions) and disorganized speech make major depressive disorder less likely in this case.

Option C- Generalized anxiety disorder:

  • Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive and uncontrollable worry and anxiety about various aspects of life. It does not typically involve hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized speech suggesting a different diagnosis, such as schizophrenia

Option D - Bipolar disorder:

  • Bipolar disorder involves episodes of mania or hypomania, alternating with periods of depression. This patient's symptoms are more indicative of schizophrenia rather than bipolar disorder. The presence of hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized speech is more characteristic of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with fever, constitutional symptoms, purpuric lesions on limbs, and targetoid lesions on hands . What is the diagnosis based on the image given below ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stevens-Johnson Syndrome SJS:

  • The image and clinical features are consistent with diagnosis of Steve Johnson’s syndrome
  • Skin shows Sheets of erythema developing over the body which breakdown at places of friction
  • Eroded areas with erythema, this is where body surface area
  • Severe kind of drug reaction.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Drug induced pigmentation:

  • Caused by Minocycline- given to acne patient
  • presents with Black blue pigmentation or scars

Option C - Acute Generalized exanthematous Pustulosis:

  • Sudden appearance of sterile pustules
  • Non-follicular confluent pustules
  • Predominantly over face or flexures
  • Accompanied with Leukocytosis and fever

Option D - Erythema Multiforme:

  • Erythema multiforme is characterized by targetoid lesions but is usually milder and does not involve extensive mucosal surfaces or show the severity seen in TEN. The laboratory findings are not consistent with erythema multiforme.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male sustained a midshaft fracture of the humerus in a recent motorcycle accident. He presents to the emergency department with weakness and loss of function in the posterior part of the forearm. On examination, he is unable to extend his wrist and fingers, and there is a noticeable wrist drop. Sensation on the dorsum of the hand is also diminished. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Radial nerve:

  • In this patient with a mid-shaft humeral fracture, the radial nerve is most likely affected.
  • It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5-T1) and travels down the radial groove of the humerus.
  • Fractures of the mid-shaft of the humerus can result in radial nerve injury, leading to weakness in the posterior compartment of the forearm.
  • Clinical features of radial nerve injury include:
  • Wrist Drop: The patient is unable to extend the wrist and fingers, resulting in a characteristic wrist drop.
  • Sensory Loss: Sensation is diminished on the dorsum of the hand.
  • Associated Fracture: Radial nerve injuries often occur in association with fractures of the mid-shaft of the humerus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Median nerve:

  • Presentation: The median nerve primarily innervates the flexors in the forearm.
  • Injury to the median nerve can result in weakness in forearm flexion and opposition of the thumb.
  • Sensory loss involves the lateral palm and digits, sparing the dorsal aspect.

Option B - Ulnar nerve:

  • Presentation: The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic hand muscles.
  • Ulnar nerve injury leads to weakness in intrinsic hand muscles, causing difficulty with fine motor movements.
  • Sensory loss involves the ulnar side of the hand and the fourth and fifth digits.

Option D - Axillary nerve:

  • Presentation: The axillary nerve supplies the deltoid muscle.
  • Injury to the axillary nerve can result in weakness during abduction of the shoulder, known as "deltoid paralysis."
  • Sensation is typically unaffected.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic gastritis presents with epigastric pain and bloating. Endoscopy reveals erosive changes in the gastric mucosa. Pepsin, a key digestive enzyme, is primarily secreted by cells located in which anatomical region of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pylorus:

  • Chief cells: Found in the gastric glands, chief cells are responsible for secreting pepsinogen, the precursor of pepsin.
  • Activation of pepsinogen: Pepsinogen is activated to pepsin by the acidic environment of the stomach. This activation is facilitated by the acidic pH resulting from the secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) by parietal cells.
  • Location in the fundus: While parietal cells in the fundus also contribute to the acidic environment necessary for pepsin activation, the primary site for oxyntic/chief cells is the fundus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Antrum: The antrum of the stomach contains a pyloric gland and its main feature is the presence of gastrin-secreting G cells

Option C - Body: Chief cells can also be present in the body of the stomach but the best answer is fundus .

Option D - Pylorus: Gastrin is produced in the pylorus

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a family history of hypercholesterolemia is started on a statin for the management of elevated cholesterol levels.

The statin inhibits 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase, a key enzyme in cholesterol synthesis. However, further investigation reveals that despite statin therapy, the patient's cholesterol levels remain elevated. Which of the following enzymes, acting downstream of HMG-CoA reductase, is now considered the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis, potentially contributing to the insufficient response to statin therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 3 - Squalene epoxidase:

  • HMG-CoA Reductase Inhibition: Statins primarily inhibit 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase, the enzyme responsible for converting HMG-CoA to mevalonate. Mevalonate is a key precursor in the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

  • Rate-Limiting Step: While HMG-CoA reductase is often considered the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, the downstream enzyme, squalene epoxidase, becomes rate-limiting when statins are used. This is because the inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase results in the accumulation of upstream metabolites, including mevalonate, which may bypass the inhibited enzyme and continue further downstream in the pathway.

  • Squalene Epoxidase: Squalene epoxidase is responsible for converting squalene to 2,3-oxidosqualene, a critical step in the synthesis of cholesterol. Inhibition of squalene epoxidase can lead to decreased cholesterol synthesis.

  • Insufficient Response to Statin Therapy: In cases where cholesterol levels remain elevated despite statin therapy, targeting enzymes downstream of HMG-CoA reductase, such as squalene epoxidase, may be explored as an alternative approach to further reduce cholesterol synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option 1 - Lanosterol synthase:

  • Function: Lanosterol synthase catalyzes the conversion of 2,3-oxidosqualene to lanosterol, an intermediate in cholesterol biosynthesis.

  • Clinical Relevance: While lanosterol synthase is a key enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway, it is not a common target for cholesterol-lowering therapies. Inhibition of lanosterol synthase is not a primary approach in managing hypercholesterolemia.

Option 2 - Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase:

  • Function: Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase is involved in the synthesis of isoprenoid intermediates, including farnesyl pyrophosphate.

  • Clinical Relevance: Isoprenoids play a role in post-translational modification of proteins, including some involved in cholesterol metabolism. However, targeting farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase is not a common strategy for cholesterol reduction.

Option 4 - Sterol-C4-methyl oxidase:

  • Function: Sterol-C4-methyl oxidase is involved in the conversion of lanosterol to 4,4-dimethylcholesta-8,14,24-trien-3β-ol.

  • Clinical Relevance: This enzyme acts downstream of squalene epoxidase, and its inhibition is not a common target for cholesterol-lowering drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct thrombin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lepirudin:

  • Lepirudin is a medication that belongs to a class of drugs known as direct thrombin inhibitors.
  • Lepirudin directly inhibits thrombin, a key enzyme involved in the coagulation cascade. By binding to thrombin, lepirudin prevents the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin and inhibits the formation of blood clots.
  • Lepirudin is typically administered by intravenous infusion

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Warfarin:

  • Warfarin is a Vitamin K+ Antagonist
  • The drug Warfarin is an inhibitor of the enzyme epoxide reductase.
  • Warfarin stops the activation of the clotting factors, but it takes days, not hours. Therefore it is slow slow-acting

Option C -Heparin:

  • It is an indirect thrombin inhibitor
  • It acts indirectly by activating plasma antithrombin 3
  • In higher doses, it inhibits platelet aggregation and prolongs bleeding time

Option D - Rivaroxaban:

  • It is a direct factor Xa inhibitor
  • It is used for the prophylaxis and treatment of DVT

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which among the following nerves supply vocal cords above the larynx?
questions.solution:

  • Motor supply: All muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid (Posterior cricoarytenoid - abductor)

Option D - External laryngeal nerve:

questions.text: What is the Composition of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - A - Etonogestrel + Ethinyl Estradiol:

  • The provided image represents a NuvaRing or vaginal ring.
  • It contains Etonogestrel (0.120 mg/day) + Ethinyl Estradiol (0.015 mg/day)
  • The ring is inserted within 5 days after the onset of the menstrual cycle. It is effective for 3 weeks and is removed on the 4th week for withdrawal bleeding. Then, a new ring can be inserted. The ring can be removed during intercourse but should be replaced within 3 hours.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nonoxynol-9:

  • Nonoxynol-9 is primarily used as a spermicidal agent. It works by disrupting the cell membranes of sperm, thereby preventing them from reaching and fertilizing an egg.
  • It is found in various forms, including gels, foams, creams, and lubricated condoms. These products are designed to be used intravaginally before sexual intercourse.

Option C - Estradiol + Norelgestromin:

  • This composition is of EVRA patch.
    • This is a hormonal patch of size 4 cm approx. applied over the arm or abdomen.
    • The patch has to be changed every week until 3 weeks & the 4th week is given as a break & the patient will have periods.

Option D - Etonogestrel:

  • Etonogestrel works primarily by inhibiting ovulation, preventing the release of an egg from the ovaries. It also thickens cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to reach the egg, and alters the lining of the uterus, making it less receptive to a fertilized egg.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of paralysis due to a spinal cord injury is admitted to the hospital for the management of pressure sores. On examination, a deep ulcer is noted, shown as below. The wound has visible undermining of adjacent tissues. Which stage of pressure sores is most appropriate for describing the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage 4:

  • Pressure sores, also known as pressure ulcers or bedsores, are localized injuries to the skin and/or underlying tissue that usually occur over a bony prominence as a result of pressure, or pressure in combination with shear and/or friction. Staging pressure sores helps healthcare professionals communicate the severity of the wound and guide appropriate management. The stages are as follows:
  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema (redness) of intact skin, indicating potential damage.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and/or dermis. The ulcer is superficial and presents as an abrasion, blister, or shallow crater.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss involving damage or necrosis of subcutaneous tissue. The ulcer extends down to, but not through, underlying fascia.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin loss with extensive destruction, tissue necrosis, or damage to muscle, bone, or supporting structures. Undermining or tunneling may be present.
  • Unstageable: Full-thickness skin or tissue loss in which the depth of the ulcer is obscured by slough (yellow, tan, gray, green, or brown) or eschar (tan, brown, or black) in the wound bed.
  • In the presented case, the description of a deep ulcer involving muscle and potentially bone, with visible undermining of adjacent tissues, is indicative of a Stage 4 pressure sore. Stage 4 pressure sores are characterized by severe tissue damage, including involvement of deeper structures beyond the skin and subcutaneous tissue. These wounds often require advanced wound care and may necessitate surgical interventions for optimal healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage 1:

  • Description: Non-blanchable erythema (redness) of intact skin.
  • Indication: Indicates potential damage to the skin.
  • Management: Focus on relieving pressure and preventing progression.

Option B - Stage 2:

  • Description: Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and/or dermis. The ulcer is superficial and presents as an abrasion, blister, or shallow crater.
  • Indication: Involves damage to the outer layers of the skin.
  • Management: Emphasizes wound care, infection prevention, and pressure relief.

Option C - Stage 3:

  • Description: Full-thickness skin loss involving damage or necrosis of subcutaneous tissue. The ulcer extends down to, but not through, underlying fascia.
  • Indication: Involves deeper tissue layers.
  • Management: Requires more intensive wound care, potential surgical interventions, and continued pressure relief.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to a recent decline in cognitive function, personality changes, and myoclonic jerks. His parents report a history of measles infection when he was 18 months old. Physical examination reveals abnormal eye movements and cognitive regression. An electroencephalogram (EEG) demonstrates periodic stereotyped high amplitude complexes, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an elevated measles antibody titer. What complication of the previous measles infection is most likely responsible for the current neurological presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE):

  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive, and fatal complication of measles virus infection. It occurs years after an initial measles infection, typically during childhood or adolescence, though it can manifest even a decade or more after the acute measles illness.
  • SSPE is believed to result from persistent measles virus infection in the brain, leading to chronic inflammation, demyelination, and progressive neurological decline. The characteristic symptoms include cognitive decline, behavioral changes, myoclonic jerks, seizures, and vision abnormalities. EEG findings often reveal periodic complexes, which are abnormal electrical patterns in the brain.
  • The diagnosis of SSPE is supported by clinical features, a history of previous measles infection, elevated levels of measles antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and specific EEG patterns. There's currently no definitive cure for SSPE, and the condition is usually fatal. Treatment mainly focuses on supportive care to manage symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Measles encephalitis:

  • Measles encephalitis is an acute complication of measles characterized by brain inflammation. It occurs during or shortly after acute measles infection. It's distinct from SSPE, which has a more insidious onset and occurs years after the initial infection.

Option C - Measles-associated acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM):

  • ADEM is an immune-mediated inflammatory disorder of the central nervous system that can occur after viral infections, including measles. It usually presents as a monophasic illness with acute neurological symptoms. While it can follow measles infection, it doesn't typically have the progressive course seen in SSPE.

Option D - Measles-related febrile seizures:

  • Febrile seizures can occur during acute measles infection, especially in young children. However, they are typically self-limited and resolve without leading to chronic neurological impairment.

questions.text: A young male was accompanied by his mother to the clinic complaining of aggressive behavior towards his friends and lack of empathy.He wouldn't spend time on homework for school. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option - C:

  • Antisocial personality disorder: Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a disregard for the rights of others and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often engage in impulsive and irresponsible behavior, have difficulties conforming to social norms, and may exhibit a pattern of deceit and manipulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paranoid personality disorder: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others, interpreting their motives as malevolent. Individuals with paranoid personality disorder often exhibit a pattern of suspicion, hyper-vigilance, and a reluctance to confide in others.

Option B - Schizoid personality disorder: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of social detachment and emotional coldness. Individuals with this disorder typically have limited interest in social relationships, prefer solitary activities, and often appear emotionally distant. They tend to avoid close relationships and may show a lack of desire for social interaction.

Option D - Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Emotionally unstable personality disorder, also known as borderline personality disorder, is characterized by a pervasive pattern of instability in mood, self-image, and interpersonal relationships. Individuals with this disorder often experience intense and rapidly shifting emotions, engage in impulsive behavior, and have difficulties maintaining stable relationships.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and a noticeable deviation of the uvula to the contralateral side upon saying "ah." On examination, it is observed that the patient's ability to elevate the soft palate during speech is impaired. Which of the following nerves is primarily responsible for the motor innervation of the affected muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vagus nerve (CN X):

  • In the scenario described in the question, the patient presented with difficulty swallowing and a noticeable deviation of the uvula to the contralateral side upon saying "ah." This deviation of the uvula is a clinical sign known as uvula deviation, and it typically occurs due to the dysfunction or weakness of the muscles of the soft palate, including the palatoglossus.
  • It plays a crucial role in elevating the soft palate during speech and swallowing.
  • The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is responsible for the motor innervation of the palatoglossus muscle.
  • Dysfunction of the vagus nerve can result in impaired soft palate movement, leading to difficulty in swallowing and the characteristic uvula deviation seen upon phonation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII):

  • Muscles Innervated: Intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.
  • Function: The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the tongue, controlling movements necessary for speech and swallowing.

Option C - Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX):

  • Muscle Innervated: Stylopharyngeus muscle.
  • Function: The glossopharyngeal nerve primarily innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle, which is involved in the elevation of the pharynx during speech and swallowing.

Option D - Facial nerve (CN VII):

  • Muscles Innervated: Muscles of facial expression.
  • Function: The facial nerve controls muscles responsible for facial expressions, not directly involved in the muscles related to palate elevation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a sudden onset of tense, fluid-filled blisters on her abdomen and extremities. On examination, the blisters are widespread, with a predilection for flexural areas. Biopsy reveals subepidermal blistering and direct immunofluorescence shows linear IgG and C3 deposits along the basement membrane zone. The pathogenesis of the condition involves a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction against a protein complex. This protein complex plays a crucial role in anchoring the epidermis to the underlying basement membrane. What is the specific function of the protein complex targeted in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Epithelial cell to basement membrane:

Bullous Pemphigoid and Type 2 Hypersensitivity:

  • Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering skin disorder characterized by a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • In bullous pemphigoid, autoantibodies, primarily IgG, target components of the hemidesmosomal protein complex.
  • The binding of autoantibodies to hemidesmosomal proteins, such as BP180 (also known as collagen XVII), leads to inflammation and the formation of subepidermal blisters.

Function of Hemidesmosomes:

  • Hemidesmosomes are adhesive protein complexes that play a crucial role in anchoring the epidermis to the underlying basement membrane in the skin.
  • Specifically, hemidesmosomes connect keratinocytes (epidermal cells) to the extracellular matrix components in the basement membrane, providing structural integrity to the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cell to cell adhesion:

  • Function: Desmogleins are a type of desmosomal cadherin, and they play a crucial role in desmosomes, which are structures responsible for cell-to-cell adhesion in the epidermis.
  • Relevance: Desmogleins are targeted in autoimmune blistering disorders such as pemphigus vulgaris, where autoantibodies against desmogleins lead to loss of cell adhesion between keratinocytes.

Option B - Cell-ECM interactions:

  • Function: Integrins are transmembrane receptors that mediate cell adhesion to the extracellular matrix (ECM). They play a role in cell-ECM interactions.
  • Relevance: While important for overall skin structure and adhesion, integrins are not the primary target in bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid primarily involves autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins.

Option D - Connects intermediate filaments:

  • Function: Plakins are cytolinker proteins that connect intermediate filaments to other cytoskeletal elements, contributing to the structural stability of cells.
  • Relevance: Mutations in plakins can lead to skin diseases, but they are not the primary target in bullous pemphigoid or other autoimmune blistering disorders.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a constellation of symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and a beefy, red tongue. Upon further investigation, it is revealed that her diet primarily consists of corn-based products. Laboratory tests show a deficiency in a crucial coenzyme involved in cellular metabolism. Which of the following coenzymes is likely deficient in this patient, contributing to the development of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD):

  • Pellagra Symptoms: The symptoms described, including dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and a beefy, red tongue, are classic manifestations of pellagra.
  • Cause of Pellagra: Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin, which includes nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. These compounds are precursors of the coenzyme nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and its phosphorylated form (NADP).
  • NAD in Cellular Metabolism: NAD is a crucial coenzyme involved in various cellular processes, including glycolysis, the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation. It plays a vital role in redox reactions as a hydrogen acceptor, facilitating the transfer of electrons.
  • Corn-Based Diet: In this case, the patient's primary diet consisting of corn-based products contributes to the niacin deficiency. Corn contains niacin in a bound form (niacytin), which is not readily bioavailable. Inadequate niacin intake leads to pellagra.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Coenzyme Q10:

  • Deficiency Disease: Coenzyme Q10 deficiency.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms can include muscle weakness, fatigue, and cardiomyopathy. Coenzyme Q10 plays a role in mitochondrial function and energy production.

Option C - Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP):

  • Deficiency Disease: Beriberi (vitamin B1/thiamine deficiency).
  • Clinical Presentation: Wet beriberi involves cardiovascular symptoms like heart failure, while dry beriberi includes neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy.

Option D - Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP):

  • Deficiency Disease: Vitamin B6 deficiency.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms can include dermatitis, glossitis, and peripheral neuropathy. PLP is involved in amino acid metabolism.

questions.text: Which lung tumour is asscociated with marker ‘’ CALRERTININ”?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Malignant Mesothelioma:

  • Mesothelioma is a lung tumour that grows towards the base of the pleura
  • Presents with pleural effusion
  • Asbestosis is one of the risk factor for the disease

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is associated with markers p40 and p63

Option C - Adenocarcinoma: NAPSIN A, MUC1 and "TTF 1" are the markers for Adenocarcinoma

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of GLP-1 AGONISTS?

choices.text: Induces Insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, inhibits glucagon release from alpha cells, slows gastric emptying, and suppresses appetite
Binds to sulphonylurea receptors⇒ closure of ATP dependent potassium channels⇒ depolarisation⇒ Insulin release
ATP blocks ATP-sensitive K+ channel due to that K+ staying inside and Ca + + entering into the cell ⇒ Storing Insulin inside ⇒ Release of Insulin outside the cell.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Induces Insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, inhibits glucagon release from alpha cells, slows gastric emptying, and suppresses appetite:

  • This is the mechanism of action of GLP-1 agonists
  • Exenatide and liraglutide belong to GLP-1 agonists

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Binds to sulphonylurea receptors ⇒ closure of ATP dependent potassium channels ⇒ depolarisation ⇒ Insulin release:

  • This is the MOA of Meglitinide/D- phenylalanine analogues
  • Repaglinide and Nateglinide belong to this group

Option C - ATP blocks ATP-sensitive K+ channel due to that K+ staying inside and Ca + + entering into the cell ⇒ Storing Insulin inside ⇒ Release of Insulin outside the cell:

  • This is the MOA of Thiazolidinediones
  • Pioglitazone belongs to this group

Option D - None of the above

questions.text: A 28 year old male patient came to the emergency after fighting with a colleague. His vitals are stable and the wound is shown in the image given below. Identify the type of mechanical wound

  • They are classified into Split, stretch, grind, cut and tear lacerations

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contusion:

Option C - Abrasion:

Option D - Fracture:

  • It is a form of injury that is associated with bone or tooth .Fracture is defined as breakage due to direct or indirect force

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hypopigmented skin lesions on the trunk and extremities. Skin biopsy reveals the presence of acid-fast bacilli, confirming the diagnosis of paucibacillary (PB) leprosy. The patient has a low bacterial load, and the primary aim of treatment is to eliminate the bacilli and prevent disease progression. Which of the following drug regimens is commonly used in the management of paucibacillary leprosy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine:

  • Paucibacillary (PB) leprosy is a form of leprosy characterized by a low bacterial load and the presence of a few skin lesions. The standard drug regimen for the management of paucibacillary leprosy includes three main drugs: rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine.
  • Rifampicin: This antibiotic is a key component in the treatment of leprosy. It is effective against Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of leprosy.
  • Dapsone: Another important drug in the treatment of leprosy, dapsone is a bacteriostatic agent that inhibits the growth of M. leprae.
  • Clofazimine: This drug is specifically added to the regimen for paucibacillary leprosy. Clofazimine has anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties and plays a role in preventing relapse.
  • This combination of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine is considered the standard multidrug therapy (MDT) for paucibacillary leprosy. The regimen is effective in eliminating the bacteria, reducing symptoms, and preventing the progression of the disease. It is crucial for patients to complete the full course of treatment to achieve optimal outcomes and prevent the development of drug resistance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rifampicin and dapsone: This combination is part of the multidrug therapy (MDT) used for the treatment of leprosy. It is often prescribed in cases of paucibacillary leprosy, where there are a few skin lesions and a low bacterial load.

Option C - Rifampicin, dapsone, and ethionamide: Ethionamide is not a standard drug in the treatment of leprosy. Rifampicin and dapsone are commonly used, but ethionamide is typically used for the treatment of tuberculosis and is not part of the standard leprosy regimens.

Option D - Rifampicin, dapsone, and ofloxacin: This combination is not the standard regimen for leprosy. Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic and is not typically used as a first-line drug in leprosy treatment.

questions.text: Which among the following arteries do not contribute to Little's area?

Option B - Septal branch of superior labial artery:

Option C - Septal branch of sphenopalatine artery:

  • It is a part of Little’s area.

questions.text: Identify the shape of the maternal pelvis shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anthropoid:

  • The anthropoid pelvis has an oval or round inlet with a prominent anteroposterior diameter.
  • Face-to-pubis delivery is most commonly associated with this pelvis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gynecoid:

  • Rounded and wide.
  • This is considered the typical female pelvis. It's favorable for childbirth due to its round shape, allowing for easier passage of the baby.

Option B - Android:

  • This pelvis is more common in men but can be found in some women. It may present challenges such as deep transverse arrest during childbirth due to its narrower shape.

Option C - Platypelloid:

  • Flat and broad.
  • This type of pelvis is the least common and may also present challenges during childbirth. The flat shape may affect the descent of the baby through the birth canal.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain, localized tenderness, and rebound tenderness. The patient is suspected to have acute appendicitis, and the decision is made to proceed with an appendectomy. The surgeon plans to utilize the below depicted incision for the procedure. What is the name of the incision shown below marked as 4?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mcburney's incision:

  • McBurney’s Incision:
  • Commonly known as the muscle-split or gridiron incision, McBurney's incision is a transverse cut aligned with the skin crease, positioned 1 inch above and forward from the anterior superior iliac spine.
  • Alternatively, an oblique incision may be made, centered at McBurney's point along the line from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus.
  • The aponeurosis of the external oblique is incised obliquely downwards and medially, following the direction of its fibers. Subsequently, the internal oblique and transversus muscles are split along the line of their fibers and retracted without dividing them.
  • Upon closure, these muscles snap together, leaving the anterior abdominal wall nearly undamaged.
  • This incision is commonly employed for appendectomies but can also be utilized in the left iliac fossa for left-sided colonic pathology.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1:

  • Subcostal Incision (Kocher Incision): Referred to as the Kocher incision, this technique is employed on the right side for gallbladder surgery and on the left side for spleen exposure.
  • The skin incision initiates at the midline and extends parallel to, and 1 inch below, the costal margin.

Option B - 6:

  • The transverse incision, it is performed slightly to the side and below the umbilicus.
  • This type of incision facilitates access to the colon, duodenum, and pancreas and is commonly employed due to its lower risk of affecting the nerve supply to the abdominal muscles.

Option C - 5:

  • The Pfannenstiel incision is a horizontal skin incision, positioned two finger-breadths (approximately 5 cm) above the symphysis pubis.
  • It extends towards the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and concludes 2–3 cm medially to ASIS on both sides.
  • This incision, measuring 12 cm in a convex shape, provides access to the lower gastrointestinal tract, urinary tract, and pelvic reproductive organs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old previously healthy female presents to the emergency department with a severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is obtained. The CSF findings reveal an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), an elevated protein concentration, and a decreased glucose concentration. What type of meningitis is most likely responsible for these CSF findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bacterial meningitis:

  • The CSF findings described in the question (elevated white blood cell count predominantly consisting of neutrophils, elevated protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration) are indicative of bacterial meningitis. Bacterial meningitis is characterized by an acute and severe inflammation of the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
  • Key CSF findings in bacterial meningitis include:
  • Elevated White Blood Cell Count (WBC): Bacterial meningitis typically presents with a markedly elevated WBC count in the CSF, and the predominant cell type is often neutrophils. Neutrophils are the first responders to acute inflammation.
  • Elevated Protein Concentration: The inflammatory response in bacterial meningitis leads to increased protein levels in the CSF due to the presence of immune cells and other inflammatory mediators.
  • Decreased Glucose Concentration: Bacterial organisms consume glucose in the CSF, leading to a decrease in glucose levels. This is a characteristic feature of bacterial meningitis and helps differentiate it from other types of meningitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Viral Meningitis (Aseptic Meningitis):

  • Viral meningitis is often characterized by a lymphocytic pleocytosis in the CSF (predominantly lymphocytes), a mildly elevated protein concentration, and a normal or slightly decreased glucose concentration. Viral meningitis is usually a milder form of meningitis compared to bacterial meningitis.

Option C - Fungal Meningitis:

  • Fungal meningitis can present with an elevated WBC count, often with a predominance of lymphocytes, an elevated protein concentration, and a normal or mildly decreased glucose concentration. The presentation may be more subacute or chronic compared to bacterial meningitis.

Option D - Tuberculous Meningitis:

  • Tuberculous meningitis can present with an elevated WBC count (usually lymphocytes), an elevated protein concentration, and a decreased glucose concentration. The chronic course and granulomatous inflammation are characteristic features.
