questions.text: Which among the following is the appropriate preoperative fasting recommendation?

choices.text: 6 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 6 hours for breast milk in infants:

  • Preoperative fasting period is a prior time that is prescribed before any procedure accomplished either general anesthesia, sedation, or regional anesthesia.
  • In this period, no oral intake of solids or liquids is allowed. This fasting is mandatory for the safety process to protect gastric contents from pulmonary aspiration and is supposed to happen at any time during the anesthesia.
  • It is considered 6 hours for milk as well as light meals, and 8 hours for fatty foods.
  • The collective fasting recommendation is two hours for clear and light liquids, four hours for breast milk, and six hours for solid foods, infant formula, light meals, and non-human milk.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 5 hours for solids in adults:

  • Six hours of preoperative fasting is recommended for solid food in adults

Option B - 6 hours for breast milk in infants:

  • Four hours of preoperative fasting is recommended for breast milk.

Option D - 10 hours for solids in infants:

  • It is recommended that 8 hours for solid foods in preoperative fasting before anesthesia. It should be kept in mind that cereal and baby food are solid foods.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents to the emergency department with the following fracture, the image of which is given below. What among the following is the appropriate management of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Dynamic Hip Screws:

  • This is the most appropriate treatment for undisplaced fractures of the neck of the femur. Where the Trabecular pattern is maintained in a complete fracture as shown in the image for grade 2 fracture in gardens classification

  • It involves surgically opening the hip joint, reducing the fracture by aligning the bone fragments, and then fixing them in place using cannulated screws.

  • This technique provides stable fixation, allows for early mobilization, and promotes better healing of the fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Spica cast immobilization:

  • This treatment option involves aligning the fractured bone fragments without surgery and immobilizing the hip joint using a cast.

  • However, closed reduction is not suitable for displaced fractures of the neck of the femur, as it is challenging to achieve and maintain proper alignment without surgical intervention.

  • It is done in grade 1.

Option B - Hemiarthroplasty:

  • Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the femoral head with a prosthetic component while preserving the patient's native acetabulum.

  • It is typically indicated in elderly patients with displaced fractures and pre-existing hip joint pathology, such as severe arthritis.

  • However, in this case, the patient's age and the absence of significant hip joint pathology suggest that hemiarthroplasty is not the most appropriate treatment option.

  • It is done in grade 3 or 4.

Option C - Total hip arthroplasty:

  • Total hip arthroplasty is a procedure where both the femoral head and the acetabulum are replaced with prosthetic components. It is typically performed in patients with severe hip joint arthritis or fractures that involve the hip joint.

  • In this case, where the fracture is limited to the neck of the femur, total hip arthroplasty is not necessary.

  • It is done in grade 3 or 4.

questions.text: How many stages are present under the Kubler-Ross model of grief?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Five:

  • Kübler-Ross originally developed stages to describe the process patients with terminal illness go through as they come to terms with their own deaths; it was later applied to grieving friends and family as well, who seemed to undergo a similar process. There are five stages under this model. It includes:
    • Denial
    • Anger
    • Bargaining
    • Depression
    • Acceptance

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Three: Kubler ross model of grief include 5 stages

Option C - Four: Kubler ross model of grief include 5 stages

Option D - Six: Kubler ross model of grief include 5 stages

questions.text: What is the clinical feature depicted in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Koebner’s phenomenon:

  • Koebner’s phenomenon refers to the emergence of new psoriatic lesions in the healthy skin regions following an injury/trauma to psoriatic patients. Psoriatic lesions develop along the lines of trauma. Isomorphic response (similar morphology lesions are developed). It will be an all or none phenomenon. This phenomenon is one of the signs of psoriasis.

Category

Examples

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Psoriasis, Lichens planus, Vitiligo

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Warts, Molluscum

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

Darier disease, Erythema multiforme

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Pemphigus vulgaris, Lupus erythematosus

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dermographism:

  • Dermatographism is also known as dermographism urticaria, or urticaria factitia, is an urticarial eruption upon pressure or trauma to the skin. This is the most common physical urticaria.
  • Derma means skin and graphism means writing, together means writing on skin. Physical urticaria is caused by physical force, like sun, water, heat, etc. Linear streaks of urticaria on lines of stroking. Whatever has been written, it gets imprinted.u.

Option B - Nikolsky sign:

  • Pemphigus Vulgaris Development of bulla or erosion when a shearing force is applied on the normal skin surrounding a vesicle or bulla.
  • Importance of Nikolsky's Sign
    • Deals with the severity and activity of the disease.
    • It checks the response to treatment.
    • Differentiate between intraepidermal positive and subepidermal disorders negative.

Option D - Auspitz sign:

  • Bedside tests are done with a blunt object scraping on the psoriatic skin. Continuous scraping produce:
  • Grattage test/ Candle sign: accentuation of scaling is increased.
  • Berkley's membrane: thin transparent membrane
  • Auspitz sign: pinpoint bleeding points.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with pain and limited range of motion in his right hip. Physical examination reveals weakness in external rotation. Which muscle is primarily responsible for external rotation of the hip?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - Piriformis:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with pain and limited range of motion in the right hip, along with weakness in external rotation. Dysfunction of the piriformis, such as tightness or irritation, can lead to symptoms like hip pain and compromised movement.
  • The piriformis muscle is a pear-shaped muscle located in the deep gluteal region, connecting the sacrum to the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Origin: Anterior surface of the sacrum.
  • Insertion: Greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Nerve Supply: Nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).
  • Function: External rotation and abduction of the hip. The piriformis also plays a role in stabilizing the hip joint

Incorrect Options:

Option 2 - Gluteus medius:

  • Origin: External surface of the ilium.
  • Insertion: Lateral surface of the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Nerve Supply: Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1).
  • Function: Abduction and medial rotation of the hip. It also helps stabilize the pelvis during the stance phase of walking.

Option C - Psoas major:

  • Origin: Lumbar vertebrae (T12-L5).
  • Insertion: Lesser trochanter of the femur.
  • Nerve Supply: Lumbar plexus (branches from L1 to L3).
  • Function: Flexion of the hip joint. It is also involved in the flexion of the lumbar vertebral column.

Option D - Adductor magnus:

  • Origin: Inferior pubic ramus and ischial tuberosity.
  • Insertion: Linea aspera of the femur.
  • Nerve Supply: Obturator nerve (anterior part) and sciatic nerve (posterior part).
  • Function: Adduction of the hip, as well as extension and medial rotation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. She reports irregular menstrual cycles and occasionally passing clots during her periods. The patient has no history of pregnancies and has not been using any form of contraception. Pelvic examination and ultrasound revealed no structural abnormalities or cysts. The hormonal evaluation shows elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone. During the discussion, the patient asks about the physiological events that lead to the initiation of menstruation. Which of the following hormonal changes is primarily responsible for the initiation of menstruation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Decreased progesterone levels:

  • Menstruation is a cyclical process that responds to hormonal fluctuations throughout the menstrual cycle. The menstrual cycle encompasses distinct phases: menstrual, proliferative, ovulatory, and secretory.
  • The onset of menstruation occurs in the menstrual phase, characterized by the withdrawal of hormonal support, primarily marked by a reduction in progesterone levels.

Menstrual Phase:

  • This phase inaugurates the menstrual cycle and involves the shedding of the endometrial lining.
  • Progesterone is secreted by the corpus luteum, which forms from the ruptured ovarian follicle post-ovulation.

Decline in Progesterone:

  • In the absence of pregnancy, the corpus luteum regresses, resulting in a significant decrease in progesterone levels.
  • Progesterone, in conjunction with estrogen, sustains the thickened endometrial lining, preparing it for the potential implantation of a fertilized egg.

Endometrial Breakdown:

  • The withdrawal of progesterone signals the blood vessels in the endometrium to constrict, leading to reduced blood flow.
  • Without hormonal support, the endometrial tissue breaks down and is expelled from the uterus, resulting in menstrual bleeding.

Role of Estrogen:

  • While estrogen also decreases during this phase, the decline in progesterone is the key factor triggering the breakdown of the endometrial tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Increased estrogen levels:

  • While estrogen is involved in the proliferative phase and is necessary for endometrial thickening, an increase in estrogen alone does not trigger menstruation.
  • It is the decline in both estrogen and progesterone that leads to the shedding of the endometrial lining.

Option C - Decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) levels:

  • The LH surge triggers ovulation, but a decrease in LH levels after ovulation is not the primary trigger for menstruation.
  • LH levels decrease after ovulation,

Option D - Increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels:

  • FSH is involved in the follicular phase, promoting the development of ovarian follicles, but it does not directly initiate menstruation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and difficulty swallowing. Upon further investigation, a muscle biopsy reveals ragged-red fibers and a defect in mitochondrial DNA. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation in the mitochondrial gene associated with mitochondrial myopathy. Further examination reveals abnormal translation initiation in mitochondrial protein synthesis. Which of the following components plays a crucial role in initiating translation in mitochondrial protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - fMet-tRNA:

  • Mitochondrial protein synthesis involves unique features distinct from cytoplasmic protein synthesis. Unlike cytoplasmic protein synthesis, mitochondrial translation initiates with a specialized formylmethionine (fMet)-tRNA, rather than methionine-tRNA (Met-tRNA). This formylmethionine initiates protein synthesis in the mitochondria.
  • Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) encodes essential components of the oxidative phosphorylation system, and defects in mitochondrial protein synthesis can lead to mitochondrial myopathies. In this case, the patient's symptoms, muscle biopsy findings, and genetic analysis pointing to a mutation in mitochondrial DNA are indicative of mitochondrial myopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - AUG codon:

  • AUG is the start codon in cytoplasmic protein synthesis.
  • It codes for methionine and initiates the translation process in the cytoplasm. In mitochondrial protein synthesis, however, the initiation involves a specialized tRNA carrying formylmethionine (fMet), not methionine.

Option B - UAA codon:

  • UAA is a stop codon. It does not play a role in the initiation of translation.
  • Instead, it signals the termination of the translation process in both cytoplasmic and mitochondrial protein synthesis.

Option D - Shine-Dalgarno sequence:

  • The Shine-Dalgarno sequence is a prokaryotic ribosomal binding site found in bacterial mRNA.
  • It helps in positioning the ribosome correctly during the initiation of translation in prokaryotes. This sequence is not present in eukaryotic mRNA, including mitochondrial mRNA.

questions.text: A 60 year old female presents with heartburn,dysphagia,regurgitation and chest pain.On endoscopy, pink velvety coloured extensions that are growing into the esophagus above the esophageal gastric junction are seen . questions.text: A male patient from Bihar exhibited symptoms of fever and myalgia. The rapid test indicated a positive result for a specific antigen, HRP-2. Based on this information, which species of Plasmodium is most likely responsible for causing the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Plasmodium falciparum:  Is one of the species of malaria-causing parasites and is the most common and deadly species responsible for malaria infections worldwide, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions

  • The HRP-2 (Histidine-rich protein 2) antigen is specific to Plasmodium falciparum.

  • It is released by the asexual blood stages of the parasite and can be detected in the blood using rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs).

  • RDTs are commonly used in resource-limited settings to diagnose malaria quickly and accurately.

  • The clinical presentation of fever and chills is consistent with malaria, as these are common symptoms of the disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Plasmodium malariae: Plasmodium malariae is another species of malaria parasite. It causes a milder form of malaria with a longer incubation period. However, the HRP-2 antigen is not typically associated with Plasmodium malariae infections, making it less likely as the causative agent in this case.

Option B - Plasmodium ovale: Plasmodium ovale is a less common species of malaria parasite. It has a similar clinical presentation to Plasmodium vivax, including recurring episodes of malaria. However, the HRP-2 antigen is not typically associated with Plasmodium ovale infections, making it less likely as the causative agent in this case.

Option D - Plasmodium vivax: Plasmodium vivax is another common species of malaria parasite. It can cause recurring episodes of malaria due to the presence of dormant liver stages (hypnozoites) that can later re-emerge and cause relapses. The HRP-2 antigen is generally not as abundant in Plasmodium vivax infections compared to Plasmodium falciparum, making it less likely as the causative agent in this case.

questions.text: India, with its diverse population and evolving socio economic landscape, experiences demographic changes over time. As of the latest available data, at what stage of the demographic cycle is India currently situated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - As of the last available data, India is in the late transition stage of the demographic cycle:

  • Pre-transition stage: Characterized by high birth rates, high death rates, and slow population growth. Typically associated with agrarian societies.
  • Early transition stage: Birth rates remain high, but death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and living conditions. This results in rapid population growth.
  • Late transition stage: Birth rates begin to decline, and the rate of population growth slows down. Death rates continue to be low, leading to a period of significant population expansion.
  • Post-transition stage: Both birth and death rates are low, resulting in very slow population growth or stabilization.
  • India has experienced a demographic transition over the past few decades. While birth rates have started to decline, the decline in death rates has been more pronounced, leading to a period of rapid population growth. As of the latest data, India is in the late transition stage, characterized by a declining birth rate but still substantial population growth. It's important to note that these stages are generalizations, and specific demographic patterns can vary within different regions of a country

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pre-transition stage:

  • Characteristics: High birth rates, high death rates, and slow population growth.
  • Associated Factors: Typically observed in agrarian societies with limited access to healthcare and modern amenities.

Option B - Early transition stage:

  • Characteristics: High birth rates persist, but death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and living conditions.
  • Associated Factors: Initial phase of industrialization and urbanization, leading to rapid population growth.

Option D - Post-transition stage:

  • Characteristics: Both birth and death rates are low, leading to very slow population growth or population stabilization.
  • Associated Factors: Advanced industrialization, improved healthcare, widespread access to education, and effective family planning programs contribute to population stability.

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of trotter’s triad?

choices.text: Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube
Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to 5-nerve involvement
Sensorineural deafness due to block of eustachian tube

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube:

  • Other components of trotter’s triad are Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis (due to 10th cranial nerve involvement))

Trotter’s triad includes:

  • Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to 5th cranial nerve involvement
  • Palatal paralysis (due to 10th cranial nerve involvement)
  • It is diagnostic of nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to 5-nerve involvement:

  • It is not a part of the trotter’s triad

Option C - Glossopharyngeal nerve paralysis:

  • It is not a part of trotter’s triad

Option D - Sensorineural deafness due to block of the eustachian tube:

  • It is not a part of the trotter’s triad

questions.text: Identify the instrument that is given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chalazion clamp:

  • A chalazion clamp, also known as a chalazion forceps or chalazion extractor, is a surgical instrument used to assist in the removal of a chalazion.
  • A chalazion is a painless lump or swelling on the eyelid caused by a blocked oil gland.
  • The clamp helps secure the eyelid and stabilize the area during the procedure
  • It is used to evert and expose the conjunctival aspect of the eyelid

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chalazion scoop:

  • It is used to scape the contents of chalazion out of the eyelids during surgery

Option C - Single tooth forceps:

  • It is used for holding tissues

Option D - Corneal forceps:

  • It is used to grasp,hold and manipulate the scleral edge of the corneal incision

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lochia rubra >Lochia serosa >Lochia alba:

  • The sequence of lochia discharge after childbirth, or during the puerperium, follows the Lochia rubra > Lochia serosa > Lochia alba pattern. This physiological process aids in the cleansing and healing of the uterine lining post-delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C are incorrect options.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with complaints of stunted growth and edema over the torso. On examination, he has pitting edema in bilateral legs, flaky dermatoses, and thin fragile hair with bands of hypopigmentation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Kwashiorkor

  • In Kwashiorkor, the child appears lethargic, edematous, along with fat sugary baby appearance, flaky paint dermatosis and flag signs of hair.

  • Kwashiorkor occurs due to protein intake deficiency, and the child has poor appetite and hence poor prognosis.

  • Skin changes: Flaky pain dermatosis (or) crazy permanent dermatosis 

  • Flag sign 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Marasmus:

  • The child with marasmus has severe malnutrition without oedema.

  • Other suggestive features are his poor socioeconomic status, poor intake, history of chronic diarrhea, apathy, and poor psychosocial development.

  • A severe form of wasting characterizes marasmus.

  • The child appears very thin (skin and bones) and has no fat.

  • The shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs are severely wasted.

  • Loss of buccal pad of fat creates an aged or wrinkled appearance (monkey facies)

  • Marasmus is characterized by low weight for height and reduced mid-upper arm circumference, reflecting muscle mass wasting and decreased body fat storage.

Option C - Progeria:

  • Progeria is a genetic condition.

  • It causes the child to age fast

Option D - Rickets:

  • In Rickets, the child has a pot belly, rachitic rosary, Harrison's sulcus, widening of the wrists, and frontal bossing

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a history of gallbladder disease is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. What preoperative guidance is essential to reduce the risk of complications?

choices.text: Drink plenty of water before surgery.
Enema on the night before surgery
NPO for specific hours before surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - NPO for specific hours before surgery:

  • Laparoscopic surgery is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that involves making small incisions in the abdomen and inserting a laparoscope (a thin tube with a camera and light source) to view the internal organs.
  • During laparoscopic surgery, the patient is under general anesthesia, which can cause nausea and vomiting if the stomach is not empty.
  • To reduce the risk of aspiration (inhaling stomach contents into the lungs), it is recommended that patients undergoing laparoscopic surgery follow NPO guidelines. The specific NPO guidelines may vary depending on the type of surgery and the individual patient's medical history, but generally, patients are advised not to eat or drink anything for several hours before the surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Eat full before surgery:

  • Eat full before surgery is incorrect advice that should not be given to the patient. Eating a full meal before surgery is not recommended as it can increase the risk of aspiration and may cause delays in the surgery.

Option B - Drink plenty of water before surgery:

  • Drink plenty of water before surgery", is also incorrect advice that should not be given to the patient. Drinking water before surgery can increase the risk of aspiration and delay the procedure. Patients are typically allowed to drink clear liquids (such as water or apple juice) up to two hours before the surgery.

Option C - Enema on the night before surgery:

  • Enema in the night before surgery", may be recommended for certain types of surgeries or patients, but it is not a standard recommendation for laparoscopic surgery. An enema can help empty the bowel and reduce the risk of complications during surgery, but this will be determined by the surgical team based on the individual patient's needs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. On cardiac auscultation, a mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotid arteries. The murmur is accentuated during the Valsalva maneuver and diminished with squatting. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis associated with this murmur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy:

  • The characteristics of the murmur described in the question, a mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotid arteries, are consistent with the murmur associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic disorder characterized by asymmetric hypertrophy of the interventricular septum, leading to left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. The murmur of HCM is often described as a systolic murmur, and its intensity can vary. The murmur is commonly heard at the left lower sternal border, but in some cases, it can be heard at the right upper sternal border and may radiate to the carotid arteries.

Key features of the murmur in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy include:

  • Location: Often heard at the left lower sternal border, but it can also be heard at the right upper sternal border.
  • Character: Mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.
  • Radiation: May radiate to the carotid arteries.
  • Changes with Maneuvers: The murmur typically increases in intensity during maneuvers that decrease LV volume (such as the Valsalva maneuver) and decreases with maneuvers that increase LV volume (such as squatting).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aortic Stenosis:

  • Aortic stenosis typically presents with a systolic ejection murmur that is heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotid arteries. Aortic stenosis may also have crescendo-decrescendo murmur but the murmur reduces with valsalva and increases with squatting.

Option B - Mitral Regurgitation:

  • Mitral regurgitation is associated with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla. It is not typically described as crescendo-decrescendo.

Option D - Pulmonary Stenosis:

  • Pulmonary stenosis is associated with a systolic ejection murmur heard at the left upper sternal border, and it may radiate to the back. It does not typically radiate to the carotid arteries.

questions.text: A newborn male, delivered at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery, is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) due to feeding difficulties and abdominal distension. The infant's mother did not report any major complications during pregnancy, and prenatal ultrasounds did not reveal any abnormalities. The baby is the first child for the parents, and there is no known family history of congenital anomalies. Which of the following is seen in the x-ray abdomen of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Double bubble sign:

  • The double bubble sign is a radiological finding seen on an abdominal X-ray or ultrasound in cases of duodenal atresia or stenosis. It is characterized by the presence of two distinct air-filled bubbles in the abdomen: one representing the stomach and the other representing the dilated portion of the proximal duodenum. This sign indicates a blockage or obstruction in the duodenum, which can result in bilious vomiting (vomiting of greenish-yellow fluid). The presence of the double bubble sign raises suspicion of duodenal obstruction.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cupola sign: seen in pneumoperitoneum

Option C - Air crescent sign: The "air crescent sign" is a radiological finding typically seen in the context of invasive fungal infections, especially pulmonary aspergillosis. It is observed on imaging studies such as chest computed tomography (CT) scans, but it is not relevant to bilious vomiting.

Option D - Multiple bubble sign: The multiple bubble sign appears in ileall atresia

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the clinic with a painful stiff back, and night cries. On examination, she has Loss of normal cervical and lumbar lordosis, gibbus and Spastic type of Paraplegia. An X-ray of the condition is shown below which shows radiolucency and loss of definition of plate margins. Which of the following is the condition mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Correct Options C - TB spondylitis:

  • The above-mentioned xray image and clinical features are suggestive of potts spine.

  • TB spondylitis, also known as Pott's spine, is a form of tuberculosis that affects the spine. It commonly presents with back pain, stiffness, and progressive deformity. The characteristic feature of TB spondylitis is the involvement of two consecutive vertebrae along with the intervertebral disc in between.

  • In this case, the imaging findings of involvement of the lower half of the T6 vertebra and the upper half of the T7 vertebra, along with the intervertebral disc, are consistent with the typical pattern seen in TB spondylitis. The destruction and involvement of the vertebral bodies and disc can lead to collapse, deformity, and spinal instability.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lumbar disc herniation:

  • Lumbar disc herniation typically involves the intervertebral discs of the lumbar spine, causing symptoms such as radicular pain and neurological deficits.

  • The involvement of specific vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs seen in this case is not characteristic of lumbar disc herniation.

Option B - Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton, causing progressive stiffness and fusion of the spine.

  • The imaging findings described in the case do not align with the typical pattern of involvement seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

Option D - Spinal metastasis:

  • Spinal metastasis refers to the spread of cancer from a primary tumor to the spine.

  • While spinal metastasis can lead to destruction of vertebral bodies and involvement of intervertebral discs, the pattern of involvement in this case, with only a portion of two consecutive vertebrae and the intervertebral disc, is more suggestive of TB spondylitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old sexually active male presents with a complaint of genital ulcers and swollen inguinal lymph nodes. Upon examination, there are enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes as shown in the image. On closer examination of the genitalia, a groove-like depression is noted along the ventral surface of the penis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):

  • The clinical presentation of painful genital ulcers, swollen inguinal lymph nodes forming "buboes," and the characteristic groove sign along the ventral surface of the penis is highly suggestive of Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). LGV is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3. The groove sign is a specific finding in LGV, often referred to as "saxophone penis." The enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes are referred to as bubo. While syphilis and herpes genitalis can cause genital ulcers, they do not typically present with the groove sign or buboes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Syphilis:

  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can present with painless genital ulcers known as chancres in the primary stage, but it does not typically cause a groove-like depression on the penis (groove sign of Greenblatt). Syphilis may also lead to swollen lymph nodes, but they are usually firm and non-tender compared to the buboes seen in LGV.

Option B - Herpes genitalis:

  • Herpes genitalis is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It presents with painful genital ulcers or sores, commonly referred to as "cold sores" or "fever blisters." While genital herpes can cause ulcers on the genitalia, it does not cause a groove-like depression on the penis (groove sign of Greenblatt) seen in LGV. Herpes genitalis may also cause swollen lymph nodes in the groin, but they are usually bilateral and not as pronounced as the buboes seen in LGV.

Option D - Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis):

  • Granuloma inguinale, also known as Donovanosis, is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It can lead to genital ulcers with a characteristic beefy-red appearance that bleeds on touch, but it does not typically cause a groove-like depression on the penis (groove sign of Greenblatt) as seen in LGV. Additionally, Donovanosis does not commonly cause tender inguinal lymph node enlargement forming buboes, which is a hallmark of LGV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of left-sided scrotal pain and swelling that worsens with prolonged standing. He also notices a dragging sensation in the left hemiscrotum. On physical examination, a non-tender mass is palpated above the left testis, which collapses when the patient is in a supine position. Doppler ultrasound confirms abnormal dilation of veins within the spermatic cord on the left side. Which of the following veins is primarily responsible for the venous drainage of the left testis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pampiniform plexus:

  • The patient's presentation of left-sided scrotal pain and swelling that worsens with prolonged standing, along with a dragging sensation, is suggestive of a varicocele.
  • Varicoceles are characterized by the abnormal dilation of veins within the spermatic cord, specifically the pampiniform plexus.
  • The pampiniform plexus is a network of veins that surrounds the testicular artery within the spermatic cord.
  • It serves as the primary drainage system for the testes.
  • In cases of varicocele, there is an enlargement and dilation of these veins, leading to scrotal discomfort and a palpable mass.
  • The symptoms often worsen with activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as prolonged standing.
  • Doppler ultrasound is a diagnostic investigation that can confirm the presence of varicoceles by visualizing the dilated veins within the spermatic cord.
  • The characteristic "bag of worms" appearance on ultrasound is indicative of varicoceles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Testicular vein:

  • The testicular vein is formed by the merging of veins within the testis, primarily the pampiniform plexus.
  • It ascends within the spermatic cord and, on the left side, drains into the left renal vein. On the right side, it drains directly into the inferior vena cava.

Option C - External pudendal vein:

  • The external pudendal vein is not directly involved in the venous drainage of the testes.
  • It primarily drains the superficial structures of the perineum and lower abdominal wall.

Option D - Renal vein:

  • The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein.
  • The right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a pH of 7.25 and an elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). Considering the respiratory status of the patient, which of the following is most likely to occur in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Right shift:

Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve

  • The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) and the saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen.
  • A right shift in the curve indicates a decrease in hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, making it easier for oxygen to be released to tissues.

Physiological Changes in Chronic Respiratory Acidosis (COPD):

  • In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and chronic respiratory acidosis, there is an accumulation of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the blood.
  • The increase in PaCO2 leads to respiratory acidosis, resulting in a decrease in blood pH (acidemia).

Effect on Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve:

  • A decrease in pH (acidosis) causes a right shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.
  • Other factors contributing to a right shift include an increase in temperature, an increase in 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG), and an increase in partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2).
  • The right shift facilitates the release of oxygen from hemoglobin in peripheral tissues where oxygen is needed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Left shift:

  • Effect: Left shift indicates an increase in hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, making it more challenging for oxygen to be released to tissues.

Option C - No shift:

  • Effect: No shift implies no significant change in hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.
  • Chronic respiratory acidosis is associated with a right shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

Option D - Bicarbonate shift:

  • Effect: The term "bicarbonate shift" is not commonly used in the context of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.
  • In Chronic Respiratory Acidosis: While the increased carbon dioxide in the blood leads to an increase in bicarbonate levels as part of the bicarbonate buffering system, the primary effect on the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is the right shift due to changes in pH and other factors

questions.text: A 10-year-old male presents with severe self-mutilating behaviour, characterized by biting of fingers and lips. Neurological examination reveals spasticity and choreoathetosis. Laboratory tests show elevated uric acid levels in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid. Family history is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HPRT1 gene, leading to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

This deficiency results in the accumulation of uric acid and a characteristic clinical triad of severe self-mutilation, spasticity, and choreoathetosis.

The self-mutilating behavior, such as biting of fingers and lips, is a hallmark feature. Elevated uric acid levels are seen in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid. The syndrome is characterized by severe neurological and behavioral abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neurofibromatosis type 1:

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 is associated with café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules. It does not present with the specific self-mutilating behavior seen in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

Option B - Tourette syndrome:

  • Tourette syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by repetitive, stereotyped movements or vocalizations called tics. It does not typically involve self-mutilation or spasticity.

Option D - Rett syndrome:

  • Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. It is characterized by loss of purposeful hand skills, repetitive hand movements, and a period of regression.

questions.text: A 65 year-old man who presents with hip pain, lytic lesions visible on hip X-ray, elevated serum calcium levels, and 42% plasma cells in the bone marrow (as shown in the image).Which of the following chromosomal translocation is associated with it?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - (11;14):

  • t(11;14) → Ig, Cyclin D1 .This chromosomal translocation is seen here
  • In Multiple Myeloma, bone marrow shows hypercellularity due to the presence of myeloma plasma cells that are more than 30%. Myeloma plasma cells are large oval-shaped cells having abundant pale blue cytoplasm with round to oval nuclei eccentrically placed with perinuclear clearing. Nuclear chromatin has a characteristic spoke wheel appearance.
  • Plasma bodies can be seen in the image.These plasma cells produce proteins that are known as antibodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - t(9;22):

  • The translocation commonly seen in the condition described in the question is t(9;22), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is suggested by the patient's age, Massive splenomegaly, leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils, and other clinical features. More than 90% of CML patients have the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the consequence of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, which creates the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

Option C - t(15;17):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), is associated with a specific chromosomal translocation known as t(15;17).
    In APL, two genes—the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene on chromosome 17 and the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene on chromosome 15—fuse to form a hybrid gene known as PML-RARA. Leukemia is caused by a hybrid gene that generates an abnormal protein that interferes with blood cells' typical function.

Option D - t(8;14):

  • A feature of B-cell malignancies is the reciprocal chromosome translocation, or t(8;14), which involves the c-myc oncogene on chromosome 8 and the heavy chain locus on chromosome 14. An acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and Burkitt's lymphoma

questions.text: A male patient, who was diagnosed with Seborrheic dermatitis, presents to the clinic complaining of breast enlargement following treatment. Which of the following drug is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Ketoconazole:

  • It is an imidazole antifungal
  • It is an anti-seborrheic
  • It induces Gynecomastia

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Clofazimine: 

  • Clofazimine is an antimycobacterial medication primarily used in the treatment of leprosy (Hansen's disease).

Option C - Rifampicin:

  • It is an antitubercular drug
  • It doesn't cause gynecomastia

Option D - Azithromycin:

  • This drug belongs to the Macrolide group
  • Used in the treatment of Chlamydia trachomatis, Legionnaires pneumonia
  • It doesn't cause gynecomastia

questions.text: A 50 year old patient ,who is a chronic drug abuser presents to the clinic with fever,chest pain,swelling in the feet,joint pain .On examination ,he has splenomegaly and Osler's nodes. Which organism is most commonly responsible for this condition associated with Intravenous drug abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Staphylococcus aureus:

  • It is the most common etiological agent for Endocarditis associated with drug abusers

  • Skin is the commonest source of infection

  • They generally causes tricuspid regurgitation

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Streptococcus mutans:

  • It is responsible for Subacute endocarditis

  • It comprises of 70% of bacterial endocarditis

  • Please add that these bacteria are normal commensals of the oral cavity and cause endocarditis following dental procedures.

  • The valves are normal and there is transient bacteremia.

Option C - Candida albicans:

  • It causes subacute endocarditis and is seen mostly in patients with prosthetic valves.

Option D - Streptococcus pneumoniae:

  • It is responsible for Acute endocarditis

  • Strep pneumo commonly causes pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis media, bacteremia and meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are included in the scheme, which has the logo as given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, Stroke:

  • The logo given in the image is of the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS).
  • Under this programme, the included diseases are CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, and Stroke.

Incorrect Options

Option A - CVD, Diabetes, Bronchial asthma: Bronchial asthma is not an included disease under the NPCDCS programme. It is one of the NCDS (Non-communicable diseases).

Option B - Diabetes, Hypertension, Bronchial asthma: It is one of the NCDS (Non-communicable diseases) but not an included disease under the NPCDCS programme

Option D - Bronchial asthma, Hypertension, CVD: Bronchial asthma and Hypertension are part of the NCDS (Non-communicable diseases) but not an included disease under the NPCDCS programme

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with pain and vesicles along the distribution of facial nerve. The patient also has facial nerve palsy with sensorineural hearing loss. The doctor suspected it to be caused by Herpes Zoster virus. Which among the following ganglions is associated with the condition in which this virus becomes latent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Geniculate ganglion:

  • Herpes zoster virus becomes latent in the geniculate ganglion.
  • Whenever there is the reactivation of this virus there is pain vesicles appear along the distribution of facial nerve, and facial nerve palsy occurs along with sensorineural hearing loss(due to involvement of the 8th cranial nerve)
  • Antiviral acyclovir is given along with steroids.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Otic ganglion:

  • Otic ganglion is not associated with Ramsay hunt syndrome

Option B - Vestibular ganglion:

  • Vestibular ganglion is not associated with Ramsay Hunt syndrome

Option C - Superior ganglion:

  • Superior ganglion is not associated with Ramsay Hunt syndrome

questions.text: A 2 year old child was brought to the clinic by his mother presenting with partial loss of vision in left eye.On examination of the eye, visual acuity is reduced, fixation pattern is central,crowding phenomenon seen.The doctor advised occlusion therapy.Which among the following is the correct treatment option of the condition that is described above?

choices.text: Occlusion of right eye for 3 days and left eye for 1 day
Occlusion of left eye for 2 days and right eye for 1 day
Occlusion of left eye for 4 days and right eye for 1 day
Occlusion of left eye for 5 days and right eye for 1 day

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Occlusion of left eye for 2 days and right eye for 1 day:

  • Occlusion therapy for Amblyopia is done in such a way that occlusion of the sound eye is done to compel the patient to use Amblyopic eye.
  • Upto 2 years, the occlusion should be done in 2:1 i.e, 2 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Occlusion of right eye for 3 days and left eye for 1 day: At the age of 3, 3 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye should be done.

Option C - Occlusion of left eye for 4 days and right eye for 1 day: At the age of four, four days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye should be done.

Option D - Occlusion of left eye for 5 days and right eye for 1 day: At the age of 5, 5 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye should be done.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with postcoital bleeding and is found to have a lesion on the cervical examination. Biopsy reveals invasive carcinoma with involvement of the lower third of the vagina and no extension to the pelvic sidewall. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Chemoradiation:

  • Chemoradiation, a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy, is often the preferred treatment for invasive cervical cancer with either >4cm size of the lesion in the cervix or upper 2/3 vagina, any lesion in parametrium, or in the lower 1/3 vagina. This approach aims to target and eliminate cancer cells both locally and systemically.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy:

  • This option involves surgical removal of the uterus, cervix, and both ovaries and fallopian tubes. However, in cases of invasive carcinoma involving the lower third of the vagina, especially when surgery alone may not address the extent of the disease, chemoradiation is often considered a more comprehensive approach.

Option B - Radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy:

  • Radical trachelectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing the cervix and upper part of the vagina while preserving fertility. It may be considered in early-stage cervical cancer(for stage 1a, and stage 1b1), but in the described case with lower third vaginal involvement, chemoradiation is generally more appropriate.

Option C - Radiation therapy:

  • While radiation therapy alone is not a preferable treatment option, the combination of chemotherapy and radiation (chemoradiation) is often preferred for more advanced cases or when cancer involves nearby structures like the lower third of the vagina.

questions.text: A male child was brought to the physician by his mother for routine evaluation. The baby was born at full term and was delivered by vaginal delivery. On examination, the child is active, makes a tower of 9 cubes and copies a circle. At what age will a child be able to do so?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 36 months:

  • At the age of 36 months, the child can build a tower of 9-10 cubes.

  • Can copy a circle.

  • Walk upstairs with alternating feet.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 24 months:

  • At the age of the 24-months child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes, turn the door knob and use pronouns like I, me, and you.

  • Baby can hold a pencil in the mid-shaft with a tripod grasp.

  • Can sit on a small chair.

  • At the age of 36 months, the child can build a tower of 9-10 cubes.

  • Can copy a circle.

  • Walk upstairs with alternating feet.

Option B - 18 months:

  • At 18 months, a child can run with uneven steps and feet wide apart.

  • Can kick a ball.

  • Builds a tower of 3 cubes.

Option C - 15 months:

  • At 15 months, a child can walk alone/independently. A child usually tries to build a tower of 2 cubes.

  • Scribbles spontaneously

  • Feeds self with a cup

questions.text: A newborn male infant is brought to the clinic for a well-baby checkup. The mother reports that the baby has not passed meconium since birth, and a physical examination reveals a distended abdomen. An X-ray is performed, and the image below is obtained. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imperforate anus:

  • The given radiograph of a newborn indicates the presence of an imperforate anus, which is a congenital condition in which the anus does not develop properly, leading to a blockage in the passage of stool.
  • Imperforate anus is a rare condition that occurs in approximately 1 in 5,000 live births. It can range from a minor defect to a complete obstruction of the anus, which can lead to life-threatening complications if not treated promptly.
  • The radiograph shows the absence of a normal gas pattern in the rectum and sigmoid colon, which is indicative of an obstruction. This is further supported by the presence of a distended abdomen, which is a common symptom of imperforate anus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meningocele:

  • Meningocele is a congenital disorder in which the spinal cord protrudes through an opening in the spinal column, resulting in a sac-like protrusion filled with cerebrospinal fluid. This condition is not visible on a radiograph of the abdomen.

Option C - Congenital megacolon:

  • Congenital megacolon, also known as Hirschsprung's disease, is a condition in which there is a lack of nerve cells in the colon, leading to an obstruction of stool passage.
  • This condition can cause abdominal distension, but it does not involve the anus and would not show an absence of gas in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

Option D - Pyloric stenosis:

  • Pyloric stenosis is a condition in which the muscle at the base of the stomach becomes thickened, leading to a narrowing of the opening between the stomach and the small intestine.
  • This condition can cause vomiting and dehydration, but it would not affect the anus and would not cause the absence of gas in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease is admitted to the intensive care unit with refractory shock. Despite aggressive fluid resuscitation and high-dose vasopressors, the patient's blood pressure remains persistently low. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated lactate level. A bedside echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's refractory shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Initiate dobutamine infusion:

  • This patient's presentation with refractory shock, persistently low blood pressure despite fluid resuscitation and vasopressors, elevated lactate level, and normal left ventricular function on echocardiogram raises the suspicion of distributive shock, potentially due to sepsis or another cause of vasodilation.
  • In cases of refractory shock with evidence of impaired perfusion (elevated lactate), when left ventricular function is normal, the addition of an inotropic agent is often necessary to improve cardiac output and tissue perfusion.
  • Dobutamine is an inotropic agent that primarily increases cardiac contractility and, to a lesser extent, heart rate. It is commonly used in the management of distributive shock, especially when there is evidence of myocardial depression or a need for increased cardiac output. Dobutamine can be particularly beneficial in septic shock, where the vasodilatory state can lead to reduced cardiac contractility.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Initiate an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP):

  • An intra-aortic balloon pump is used in the setting of cardiogenic shock, typically when there is severe left ventricular dysfunction.
  • In this case, the echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular function, making IABP less appropriate.

Option B - Administer a vasopressin infusion:

  • Vasopressin is a vasopressor that acts on V1 receptors to induce vasoconstriction.
  • While it may be used in conjunction with other vasopressors, it may not address the potential need for increased cardiac contractility in distributive shock.

Option D - Perform emergent coronary angiography:

  • The patient's presentation does not suggest acute coronary syndrome or a primary cardiac cause of shock.
  • The normal left ventricular function on echocardiogram further supports that the issue may be related to vasodilation and distributive shock rather than a primary cardiac problem.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with sharp, burning pain in the umbilical region following a recent abdominal surgery. The pain is localized to a specific area around the umbilicus. On physical examination, there is hyperesthesia and heightened sensitivity within a well-defined circular region. Which spinal nerve root corresponds to the dermatome that includes the umbilicus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T10:

  • Dermatomes are specific areas of skin innervated by a single spinal nerve.
  • The sensory distribution of dermatomes is a result of the embryological development of the spinal cord and its segmental innervation.
  • The dermatome associated with the umbilicus is primarily supplied by the T10 dermatome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - T7: The dermatome associated with T7 covers the area of the skin around the epigastric region.

Option C -  L1: The dermatome associated with L1 covers the inguinal region, and it is located below the umbilicus.

Option D - L4: The dermatome associated with L4 covers the knee and medial aspect of the leg.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking presents to the clinic with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests reveal a reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) and a decreased ratio of forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) to FVC. Chest X-ray shows bilateral diffuse interstitial markings. A lung biopsy is performed, and histological examination reveals hyperplasia of type 2 pneumocytes. Which of the following functions is primarily associated with type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Surfactant production:

  • In the presented clinical scenario, the patient's history of smoking and the histological finding of hyperplasia of type 2 pneumocytes suggest a condition affecting the lungs.
  • The reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) and the decreased ratio of forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) to FVC indicate a restrictive pulmonary pattern.
  • The histological finding of hyperplasia of type 2 pneumocytes is likely associated with an increased demand for surfactant in response to lung pathology.

Type 2 Pneumocytes and Surfactant Production:

  • Type 2 pneumocytes, also known as septal cells, are specialized epithelial cells found in the alveoli of the lungs.
  • One of the primary functions of type 2 pneumocytes is the production and secretion of pulmonary surfactant.

Surfactant Function:

  • Reduction of Surface Tension: Surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids and proteins that reduces the surface tension of the alveolar fluid.
  • Alveolar Stability: By reducing surface tension, surfactant prevents alveolar collapse during expiration and promotes stability.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mucociliary clearance:

  • Mucociliary clearance is primarily associated with the activity of ciliated cells and goblet cells in the respiratory epithelium. These cells work together to move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

Option C - Gas exchange:

  • Gas exchange occurs at the alveoli and is associated with type 1 pneumocytes, which have a thin structure that facilitates the diffusion of gases (oxygen and carbon dioxide) across the alveolar membrane.

Option D - Phagocytosis:

  • Phagocytosis, or the engulfing of particles or pathogens, is primarily attributed to alveolar macrophages, which are immune cells present in the alveoli.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with developmental delay and progressive neurologic deterioration. Physical examination reveals an exaggerated startle response, hypertonia, and a cherry-red spot on the macula. A diagnosis of lysosomal storage disorder is suspected. Which substrate accumulates in the affected cells due to the deficiency of the enzyme responsible for its degradation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 1 - Ganglioside GM2:

  • Disease: Tay-Sachs disease
  • Presentation: Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of ganglioside GM2, primarily in neurons.
  • It leads to progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, cherry-red spot on the macula, and an exaggerated startle response.
  • The disease is fatal, usually manifesting in infancy or early childhood.

Incorrect Options:

Option 2 - Sphingomyelin:

  • Disease: Niemann-Pick disease (Type A and Type B)
  • Presentation: Niemann-Pick disease is caused by a deficiency of acid sphingomyelinase, leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin.
  • In Type A, there is severe neurodegeneration, hepatosplenomegaly, and death in early childhood.
  • In Type B, there is hepatosplenomegaly and pulmonary involvement, but without severe neurologic manifestations.

Option 3 - Glucocerebroside:

  • Disease: Gaucher disease
  • Presentation: Gaucher disease is characterized by the accumulation of glucocerebroside due to a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.
  • It leads to hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone abnormalities.
  • There are different types of Gaucher disease with varying degrees of severity.

Option 4 - Cerebroside Sulfate:

  • Disease: Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD)
  • Presentation: MLD is caused by a deficiency of arylsulfatase A, resulting in the accumulation of cerebroside sulfate.
  • It leads to progressive demyelination, motor and intellectual deterioration, and eventually death.
  • There are different forms of MLD with varying onset and severity.

questions.text: A 6 year old child ,who had a history of respiratory infection 1 week back ,presents to the clinic with generalized edema,frothy urine.On investigation, there is proteinuria,hypoalbuminemia.Which among the following is the pathogenesis of the disease?

choices.text: Abnormality in IgA production and clearance and antibodies against abnormally glycosylated IgA
Immune complex disease such as hypocomplementemia and granular deposits of IgG and complement on the GBM
T cell derived factor that causes podocyte damage and effacement of foot processes
Mutation of alpha chain results in defective heterotrimer assembly

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - T cell derived factor that causes podocyte damage and effacement of foot processes:

  • This is a case of minimal change disease ,most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • Clinical features:
    • Oedema may be generalized or periorbital
    • Fatigue
    • Headache is a nonspecific finding
  • Minimal change disease is also called lipoid nephrosis.
  • Pathogenesis begins due to T-cell mediated damage to podocytes that increases the permeability to albumin and a net loss of more than 3.5 g/dl on urinalysis.
  • Hypoalbuminemia on serum analysis leads to loss of oncotic pressure and leads to oedema.
  • Causes:
    • Primary: idiopathic
    • Immunization, as in this patient
    • Infection
    • Immune stimulus
    • Secondary to lymphoma
  • Light microscopy: Normal glomeruli
  • Immunofluorescence: negative
  • Electron microscopy: effacement of podocyte foot processes

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abnormality in IgA production and clearance and antibodies against abnormally glycosylated IgA:

  • This is the pathogenesis of IgA nephropathy

Option B - Immune complex disease such as hypocomplementemia and granular deposits of IgG and complement on the GBM

  • This is the pathogenesis of Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Option D - Mutation of alpha chain results in defective heterotrimer assembly:

  • This is the pathogenesis of Hereditary nephritis

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents to the clinic with high-grade fever, nausea, vomiting, joint pain, and sore throat. She was treated with Doxycycline. Which among the following is the mechanism of action of the drug mentioned?

choices.text: Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to 30S ribosomes in the susceptible organism
Inhibit protein synthesis by interfering with the transfer of the elongating peptide chain to the newly attached aminoacyl-tRNA at the ribosome-mRNA complex
Combines with 50S ribosome subunits and interferes with translocation
Interfere with the synthesis of beta-lactam antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to 30S ribosomes in the susceptible organism:

  • This is the MOA of Tetracyclines like Doxycycline, Minocycline

Incorrect Options:

Option B  - Inhibit protein synthesis by interfering with the transfer of the elongating peptide chain to the newly attached aminoacyl-tRNA at the ribosome-mRNA complex

  • This is the MOA of Chloramphenicol

Option C  -Combines with 50S ribosome subunits and interferes with translocation:

  • This is the MOA of Macrolide antibiotics like Erythromycin, Azithromycin

Option D  - Interfere with the synthesis of bacterial cell wall:

  • This is the MOA of Beta-lactam antibiotics like Penicillin

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with a headache, neck stiffness, meningismus, and fever. The physician diagnosed the condition as Mollaret's meningitis. What is the other name for it?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Recurrent lymphocytic meningitis:

  • Also known as Mollarets meningitis

  • It is caused by HSV 2

  • Presents with fever, neck stiffness and meningismus

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tuberculous meningitis:

  • It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Option C - Pyogenic meningitis:

  • It is caused by pyogenic organisms like H .influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: In rural areas, where healthcare accessibility is a critical concern, the Indian government has implemented the ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) program. ASHA workers, grassroots-level health advocates, play a crucial role in providing basic healthcare services. For effective coverage, the government allocates one ASHA worker per a certain number of individuals. What is the purpose of this allocation?

choices.text: To ensure one ASHA worker per 500 individuals
To ensure one ASHA worker per 1000 individuals
To ensure one ASHA worker per 1500 individuals
To ensure one ASHA worker per 2000 individuals

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - To ensure one ASHA worker per 1000 individuals:

  • The allocation of one ASHA worker per a certain number of individuals is designed to ensure effective coverage and accessibility to basic healthcare services in rural areas. The specific allocation is one ASHA worker for every 1000 individuals.
  • ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHA workers are community health workers selected from the village itself. They receive basic training to act as a bridge between the community and the healthcare system. ASHA workers play a crucial role in promoting healthcare awareness, providing essential healthcare services, and facilitating community-level health interventions.
  • Purpose of Allocation: Allocating one ASHA worker per 1000 individuals is a strategic approach to ensure that there is a reasonable and manageable workload for each ASHA worker. This enables them to effectively reach and serve the population, address healthcare needs, and provide timely information about health-related programs and services.
  • It's important to note that the specific allocation may vary based on government policies and healthcare needs in different regions. The goal is to enhance healthcare access and outreach in rural areas, where geographical challenges and limited resources may otherwise hinder healthcare delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To ensure one ASHA worker per 500 individuals: This option suggests a higher density of ASHA workers per population, which might be resource-intensive and may not align with the typical allocation strategy. The standard allocation is often designed to balance coverage and efficiency.

Option C - To ensure one ASHA worker per 1500 individuals: This option suggests a lower density of ASHA workers per population, which may compromise the effectiveness of healthcare outreach. A higher number of individuals per ASHA worker might limit their ability to provide timely and comprehensive healthcare services.

Option D - To ensure one ASHA worker per 2000 individuals: Similar to option C, this suggests an even lower density of ASHA workers, potentially leading to challenges in meeting the healthcare needs of the rural population effectively. A higher workload per ASHA worker could impact the quality and reach of healthcare services.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a feeling as if the surroundings are spinning, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, sense of fullness or pressure. On PTA, sensorineural hearing loss is seen, the recruitment test is positive, the SISI score is better than 70% in two-thirds of the patients, Tone decay test is less than 20dB. Which among the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Meniere’s disease:

  • It presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, sense of fullness or pressure.
  • On PTA, sensorineural hearing loss is seen, recruitment test is positive, SISI score is better than 70% in two-thirds of the patients, Tone decay test is less than 20dB
  • Electrocochleography: SP/AP ratio is greater than 30%

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cochlear hydrops:

  • Vertigo is absent
  • Only the cochlear symptoms are present

Option B - Vestibular hydrops:

  • Patient gets typical attacks of episodic vertigo while cochlear functions remain normal

Option C - Lermoyez syndrome:

  • Here symptoms of Meniere’s disease is seen in reverse order
  • There is progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo, at which time the hearing recovers

questions.text: A male baby of 10 months of age presented to the clinic with eye pain and swelling around the eye. An abscess that discharges in the inner corner of the eyelids was noted. The Ophthalmologist diagnosed it as Dacryocystitis.Which among the following is the management for the condition?

choices.text: Intubation and balloon dilatation of NLD

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Probing:

  • If the patient is greater than 9 months, probing is done. Success rate is till 18 months (2years)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Crigglers massage:

  • If the patient is less than 9 months, Criggler massage is done

Option C - DCR surgery:

  • If the patient is more than 9 months, Probing is done

Option D - Intubation and balloon dilatation of NLD:

  • It is a new treatment option for Congenital dacryocystitis

questions.text: An ovarian cancer was removed and the tissue specimen is displayed in the image below, all of the following statements are true about the given image except?

choices.text: Most common malignant germ cell tumour

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Radioresistant tumor:

  • All ovarian cancers are radioresistant except dysgerminoma, which is radiosensitive.
  • This characteristic makes them distinct from other ovarian germ cell tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mostly Unilateral:

  • Though usually unilateral, dysgerminomas have the highest rate of bilaterality amongst germ-cell tumours.

Option B - Most common malignant germ cell tumour:

  • It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor
  • Overall the most common germ cell tumor is teratoma

Option D - PLAP is the tumor marker:

  • PLAP and LDH are raised, which serves as a tumor marker.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct dose of Vit A for Vitamin A deficiency in a child of 11 months?
questions.solution:
Correct option C- 1 lakh IU:

  • In the age group of 6-12 months, the dosage of Vitamin A is 1 lakh IU

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 50000 IU:

  • For children less than 6 months, 50000 IU of Vitamin A is given

Option B-2 lakh IU:

  • For children >1 year, 2 lakh IU of Vitamin A is given

Option D- None of the above

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman presented with a small, black nodule on the lateral side of her lower eyelid and another small, black nodule on the inner canthus, as depicted in the image below:



Approximately 3 years earlier, she had noticed a small, round-shaped, black nodule on her left lower eyelid. Over time, the nodule had gradually extended in one direction toward the proximal side of the inner canthus. Dermoscopic examination revealed arborizing vessels, multiple blue-grey globules, and large, blue-grey ovoid nests. A provisional diagnosis of linear basal cell carcinoma is established in this patient. A biopsy is performed. Which characteristic feature would be most likely found on histopathological examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nuclear palisading:

  • This patient most likely suffers from basal cell carcinoma, a slow-growing, locally invasive malignant neoplasm of the skin that arises from basal epithelial cells. It is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • This tumour typically develops in sun-exposed areas as a pearly, indurated, nodular, nontender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration.
  • The characteristic features of basal cell carcinoma are:
  • Low-grade malignancy.
  • More common in fair & dry-skinned people.
  • NUCLEAR PALISADING on histology is shown in the image below:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Keratin pearls:

  • Keratin pearls are found in squamous cell carcinoma.

Option B - Foam cells:

  • Foam cells are characterized by a type of macrophage that localize to fatty deposits on blood vessel walls. These are not seen in basal cell carcinoma.

Option C - Psammoma bodies:

  • Psammoma bodies are characterized by the concentric, intracellular calcium collections found in certain neoplasms, such as papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, papillary serous endometrial carcinoma, and meningioma. However, Psammoma bodies are not seen in basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis secondary to chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment. The healthcare provider wants to assess the severity of his liver disease and uses the Child-Pugh classification system. Which of the following components is NOT included in the Child-Pugh classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Serum creatinine levels:

  • The Child-Pugh classification is a scoring system used to assess the severity of cirrhosis and its associated complications. It evaluates the prognosis of chronic liver disease based on five clinical measures. The components of the Child-Pugh classification are as follows:
  • Serum Bilirubin Levels: This measures the extent of jaundice and reflects impaired liver function. Higher bilirubin levels contribute to a higher Child-Pugh score.
  • Serum Albumin Levels: Albumin is a protein produced by the liver. Decreased levels indicate compromised synthetic liver function, contributing to a higher score.
  • Prothrombin Time/International Normalized Ratio (PT/INR): This assesses blood clotting ability, which is influenced by the liver's production of clotting factors. Prolonged PT/INR is associated with more severe liver dysfunction.
  • Serum Creatinine Levels: While serum creatinine is a marker of kidney function, It can be assessed alongside the Child-Pugh score to evaluate the overall status of multiple organ systems, including the kidneys.
  • However, the option "D) Serum Creatinine Levels" is the correct answer because it is not part of the Child-Pugh classification. The components included in the Child-Pugh score focus on liver-related parameters, clotting factors, and the impact on other organs. Kidney function, represented by creatinine levels, is not directly incorporated into the Child-Pugh scoring system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum Bilirubin Levels:

  • Serum Bilirubin Levels is a component of the Child-Pugh classification.

Option B - Serum Albumin Levels:

  • Serum Albumin Levels is a component of the Child-Pugh classification.

Option C - Prothrombin time/International Normalized Ratio (PT/INR):

  • Prothrombin time/International Normalized Ratio (PT/INR) is a component of the Child-Pugh classification.
